author: ChazTX

title: Habit ‚Äî Daily Tracker
content:
I downloaded the app after reading these exact words on the product page:

‚ÄùWhy more than 900,000 users choose Daily Habit Tracker?

1. Unlimited amount of habits. You don‚Äôt need to pay a penny to start building as many habits as you need.
2. Ad-free. We hate ads & don‚Äôt want to bother our users‚Äù

Here‚Äôs how that went: 
- Opened the app
- Greeted with a prompt to pay for premium. 
- Dismissed the prompt. 
- Premium prompt pops up again.
(‚ÄúHmm.. that‚Äôs kind of annoying..‚Äù)
- Dismissed the prompt again.
- Started creating my first habit.
- Tried to change the color.
- Premium prompt pops up again.
- Dismissed a third time.
- Finished creating habit (minor complaint here; you can‚Äôt set the frequency to more than once a day, e.g. twice a day).
- Created two more habits.
- Tried to create a fourth.
- Premium prompt pops up again.
- Dismissed a fourth time.
(‚ÄúSurely that‚Äôs a mistake..? I was promised unlimited habits, for not even a penny.‚Äù)
- Tried to create a fourth habit.
- Premium prompt pops up again.
- Dismissed a fifth and final time.
- Uninstalled.

To be fair, the interface is pretty nice and polished. Please correct me if I‚Äôm stupid and missing something obvious, but why can‚Äôt I create more than 3 habits? I thought this app could help me structure my day and hold me accountable with reaching my goals. I don‚Äôt need an app to remind me of a maximum of 3 things. 

The premium pop-ups are a minor annoyance, and I understand that the creators need to make money. I just found their incredible frequency ironic after they touted, ‚ÄúWe hate ads & don‚Äôt want to bother our users.‚Äù They‚Äôre a bit bothersome to be honest.
author: Ianc12313

title: Habit ‚Äî Daily Tracker

But I *really* wish I could choose specific days of the week for certain habits rather than just a certain number of times in a certain number of days - the addition of that function would make this app perfect.

Haven‚Äôt been using the app regularly since. And now I can‚Äôt even add a new habit (or delete an old one and replace with a new one). The ‚Äú+‚Äù button just shows me the Premium Sign Up screen and no habit options anywhere to be found. This app is great for gamifying focus...except for the millions of videos they bombard you with. I understand needing to make money but when you have a subscription option while still having constant videos (including giving rewards for watching videos) then it feels incredibly slimy. Get rid of the video ads and hide special features (like whitelisting apps) behind a subscription instead. I would gladly pay for a subscription just because this app helps me so much, but the constant video ads on the free version really makes me not want to give them my money. 

I also really dislike the microtransaction options, but they're less obnoxious than the ads.
author: EL036515

title: Focus Plant: Forest phone lock
content:
This app is literally SO amazing! Let‚Äôs start with how it actually helps you stay away from your phone and focus. My phone is almost always on a focus session, and my screen time overall has shown a decrease. 

Another thing that makes the app stand out is how it‚Äôs an adorable game as well! I love to play it a lot, and it‚Äôs not addicting (I try my best to avoid addicting games)! Planting and taking care of all of your super cute plants is just an awesome experience. I really enjoy expanding my gardens, opening chests to reveal more gardeners, and getting to join a group. The app in general is just so cute and you can get two things at once: a great game and less screen time. 

One thing I would really like, though, would probably be a chat feature in the groups. It would be really fun to get to chat to the other members in the group, and we could feel closer to each other and help out.

But other than that, this app is TOTALLY worth trying out! I will definitely recommend it to my friends! I‚Äôve already told my dad about it and he loved the idea. Thank you so much! üíï

author: Guts Galore

title: Declutter The Mind Meditation
content:
I‚Äôve been calling on The Lord for help for some time now, I‚Äôm 29 and been abusing weed for over 12 years. (Abusing and smoking are 2 different things) I smoked every morning before work, during, and a lot more after for years. 
I took a day (kinda hard) to clean my mind without smoking for once, and I called to The Lord again and started to realize I need to love myself before others cause I‚Äôve never been happy with me, yet I was trying to help and please others. 
So I googled ‚Äúhow to be happy‚Äù and this app came up. 
With the help of God, I started to use this app to try to meditate for a change. I‚Äôm a dude so I thought it was more of a female thing for some stereotypical reason. 
But this app points out what bothers most people and has all kinds of categories to help. 
I got the free version, I don‚Äôt like to spend money on apps so I‚Äôm not saying buy anything from it, but the free advice and meditation guide that helps you learn it is really a game changer in my life. Along with music, positive mind set and of course Christs love for us. You have to call on God first and the rest will be all good man. 
Try to app out if you‚Äôve been a depressed pothead for years. May be too soon to speak but I‚Äôve used less than a hour of this apps time and I feel great. 
Thank the Lord.

title: Declutter The Mind Meditation
content:
When current meditation running you can‚Äôt go back on home screen and explore or see other episodes while current one running in background. 

Headspace is like once you played then it load full 30 min episode and then whether you are in WiFi or cellular network or break in network it doesn‚Äôt stop and continuously run in background for 30 min. So no frustration to hit play again and again if that interrupts due to breaking of network. 

There should be a way to keep mediation offline. Because there is no point of running same episode everyday over network. It stress servers and contribute global warming. I know might be less revenue generating but overall helpful for the world. 

They can charge $0.99 for premium service with features. Affordable and may be people will buy more subscription rather expensive one less. 99 cents hit buy. 10$ let me think it is worth? Oh wait there may be better service! Oh no it‚Äôs not worth 10$ let‚Äôs cancel. So why not just 99 cents and bingo done. It‚Äôs ok even if something I don‚Äôt like but not much expensive and let‚Äôs keep it.

content: You have to pay even to filter by distance. It puts you in with everyone in the ‚Äúgalaxy‚Äù unless you pay. title: Hiki: Autism ADHD & ND Dating
content: To be quite frank the two reasons I‚Äôm not giving this app 5 stars are: they caved to pressure from google and credit card companies to restrict freedom of speech. Hiki is an app for adults and we used to have a sexuality section. That section was removed and posts about sexuality are censored/removed which is very infantilizing and insulting to users. The second reason is that posts disappear after 5 months. I would like to see all of my posts. It‚Äôs entertaining to go back and see what I posted a yesr and a half ago. Why is my stuff going away after 5 months? Annoying. Other than that I really like this app because despite being marketed as a dating app, it actually works as regular social media for neurodivergent people. I‚Äôve made some friends on it.

title: Hiki: Autism ADHD & ND Dating
content:
When I logged back in after a few days, the only accounts it would show me were the ones I already turned down in the exact order I turned them down in. 

In addition, not only is it very expensive, but if the person you liked isn‚Äôt paying that price then they won‚Äôt even see your likes! You can pay $44 to send out as many likes and messages as you want to people who can‚Äôt even read them or see you! 

There‚Äôs lots of cool people on here and I love the idea of meeting other neurodivergent people, but there‚Äôs just too many barriers.

It‚Äôs disappointing to see a great app prioritize profit over user experience. I hope the developers reconsider their approach and focus on improving usability rather than monetization.

A man named Ross, started to Dox me and share sensitive information in response.

When I reported him, 2 of my posts were removed by the app.
These posts were ‚Äúinternet safety 101 cyber bullying and trolls‚Äù and one aimed at letting people know the app was being ran by Ross.

In the cyber bullying post, I spoke about what had just happened.
And it was prompted, removed.
As if someone was hiding it-
Along with that, comments I was reading on earlier posts talking about the same man- also disappeared.

This man. Is hiding his actions and abusing his power by revealing sensitive information.

I still have snaps of what he did, and I might take legal action depending on the damages.

author: ThatParticularPencil

title: Focus Tomato - Let's focus now
content:
I rarely write reviews for apps. But, I‚Äôll make an exception for this one. To put things in short, this timer is different from others visually, has simple interface, and it‚Äôs ads-free!
For the visual, I find it very pleasing as it‚Äôs not minimalistic and plain boring. The art is very aesthetically pleasing and I can tell efforts were put into this.
For the interface, beginners can instantly pick up where they need to start. The timer allows you to set however long you want your work session to be. You can also set your rest time to however you want. Compare to Focus Keeper, I think it‚Äôs overrated because you have to pay just to change the intervals of timers.
In addition, while you are working, the app gives you a variety of options to play ambient sounds in the background; Works even if you exit the app! There are also no ads in for this background noise!
Which brings me to my last point, that this is all free and has no ads in them! I believe that putting ads would ruins the whole atmosphere this app is intended to created.
Bonus: You have an option to upgrade to Tomato King permanently for $2! Just $2. Even though I may not use the data feature a lot, I‚Äôll buy it to support the creator of this app for their creativity and the vast utility this app has to offer. üåû

This is a problem, especially for ADHD people like myself who are using this to help with that. 

Other than that, it‚Äôs an excellent program that not only teaches you how to meditate but why you are doing certain activities, what they mean for your daily interactions, and what they are doing for your brain. Keep up the good work as this is the 1st meditation app I‚Äôve been able to keep up with!

author: Yorkshire-girl

title: FitMind: Mental Fitness
content: I've had a regular meditation practice for roughly 5 years now & have made more progress with Fitmind in the last 3 months than I have with other apps / on my own in the last 2 years. Liam is an excellent guide & him and his team have curated the perfect comprehensive step by step guide to begin to master the basics of various meditative practices, drawing upon ancient practices as well as modern psychology & neuroscience to do so (side note - I appreciate Liam's acknowledgment of & respect for the cultures from which these practices originated - something I feel is lacking from most other meditation apps). New content is added on a regular basis for those looking to dive deeper after finishing the first 30 days & I HIGHLY recommend listening to the podcast as well.
author: ziiilla

title: FitMind: Mental Fitness
content: I use it everyday. It has honestly been life changing for me. I applied the recommendations they give and practice daily. I have noticed a much calmer mental state on a day to day basis. It also helped get me started in a super practical way. I recommend this to anyone who is interested in meditating or has trouble quieting their mind. I am bipolar type 1 and have horrible ruminations. This has been a very useful tool for me in learning how to keep my mind focused. I really can‚Äôt say enough good things about this app.
author: aspenrhinehart

title: FitMind: Mental Fitness
content: I'm in the healthcare profession and spend time helping people with stress reduction. I have tried nearly all of the meditation apps so I can recommend. This app is the best I have tried by far, with a daily short lesson that draws upon a broad/deep knowlege base and then focused daily meditations that gradually build skills and lengthen practice time. The results are tangible. The details and timing carefully thought out. The lessons are invaluable for anyone genuinely wanting to evolve and (re)train that wild monkey of a brain and not just cover up the difficult stuff with rainbows and unicorns. (That has its place too, for sure.)The interview on the home page is a helpful deep introduction and overview and (refreshingly)not a sales pitch.
author: professorazw

title: FitMind: Mental Fitness
content:
I have been mediating off and on for my mental health issues for roughly 10 years. I have used multiple apps. Even gone through therapy that involve Metta (loving kindness). This is the first app that I have used that I can genuinely say is making a difference in my life.

Other apps offer up a smorgasbord of topics of mediation which can be overwhelming. Their approach, from my experience is not focused at all on the science of the mind, but the experience of meditation. 

FitMind gives you the researched back science up front and then teaches you how to use it. It‚Äôs truly a system to rewire your brain. It‚Äôs not a question of will this work for me, it‚Äôs a statement that this does in fact work you just need to be open and committed. For me any level of progress inspires me to learn more. To be eager for more, hungry for more and that has made all the difference in the world.

Liam your dedication to this system, the level of research you have done, how you have presented it. the commitment you have made is absolutely outstanding. I‚Äôm 10 days in and I‚Äôm blown away by how much I been able to reframe my thoughts. Years of negative thinking patterns and behaviors that I have struggled for so long to overcome are actually being recoded. This is insane.

So if you are on the fence let me tell you that you have nothing to lose and so much to gain.

Chris, Lancaster PA

author: Attorney Advertiser

title: OffScreen: Screen Time Control
content:
Dear OffScreen Team,

I hope this message finds you well.
I am a lifetime subscriber of your amazing app, and I truly appreciate the features and design you provide. However, I am facing difficulties using some of the features due to the lack of Arabic language support.

As a native Arabic speaker with limited English proficiency, I often struggle to fully understand certain parts of the app, which prevents me from benefiting from its full potential. I believe that adding Arabic as a supported language would make a significant difference for many users like myself in the Arab world.

I kindly request you to consider including Arabic language support in future updates. This would greatly enhance accessibility and improve the user experience for a large portion of your global audience.

Thank you for your time and continued efforts in developing such a helpful app.

Warm regards,
[Mohammed]

title: Study Bunny: Focus Timer
content: I really love the format of this app and all and it helps me study, but to be honest the amount of ads and their length is driving me insane. Every time I enter the app I‚Äôm greeted with a minute long ad, and every time I finish a task I‚Äôm given yet another ad. With the amount I use this app and how much I study, it‚Äôs slowly withering me down to start looking for a new app. Not to mention that I have to pay $19.99 just to get rid of the crazy amount of ads on this app?? That‚Äôs actually insane I‚Äôm sorry. At this point I‚Äôll just buy some $2 graph paper and fill in the amount of time that I study by hand or use google sheets which is FREE with no ads. Idk, I like it and all but the ads are crazy. Not to mention ANOTHER thing that has slowly driven me insane‚Äî-I listen to music a lot and like focus sounds while I study and it‚Äôs usually either playing out loud on my phone or connected via Bluetooth through headphones. Every time I enter the app, any background audio whether that be a YouTube video or a podcast or music from another app entirely cuts out and pauses. It doesn‚Äôt resume while you navigate the app or anything, it just stops. It may be related to the ads and their audios, but it‚Äôs highly inconvenient. I have to EXIT the app to resume the thing I was listening to, and when I come BACK to the app, another ad plays. Even if I check the time on my iPhone (for my Apple users) by swiping down from the top of the screen to check the time or any notifications that I might‚Äôve received, ANOTHER ad plays. In short, if you can afford to kill your battery life and never exit the app literally ever, this app is for you.

author: Kaya_19

title: Study Bunny: Focus Timer
content:
I got this app to help me study for my tests, and it does not disappoint! 
People are always ranting, saying, ‚Äò*Oh, thEsE Ads ArE sO AnnOYIng I‚Äôm gOnnA dElEtE thE App >:(‚Äòbut they aren‚Äôt even that frequent. They act like they interrupt the study session that your having. If you were just chilling, reading over a chapter in a digital textbook, zoning out to some Lofi beats, and then BAM, Mattress ad pops on at full volume, then yes, I would rate this lower and write about it, but that surely isn‚Äôt the case. 
My one issue, (not that it‚Äôs a big one) is the PRICE of the items/background in the shop. Let me paint you a picture üé® üñåÔ∏è üñºÔ∏è üåà; One coin for ten minutes, Two for twenty, and so forth. I do online school, so I average about‚Ä¶ 40 minutes per day. That‚Äôs four coins. You wanna know how much the least expensive items are? 10. You wanna know how much the MOST are? 1,000. I‚Äôm sorry, WHAT!? That is absolutely ridiculous. *No person is going to sit and study for 10 hours a day to be able to get some items in 10 days. At least, no one I know.
All in all, this app does its job and is a great study motivator/timer.

author: deerkillerbananapants

title: Avocation - Habit Tracker
content:
I‚Äôm definitely one of those people that need to write a list every day of things to accomplish or I‚Äôll end up sitting on the couch all day. I often times made lists that were lengthy and unorganized which resulted in me feeling overwhelmed or discouraged when I didn‚Äôt finish everything. So I went on the hunt for an app to help motivate me and this app is exactly what I‚Äôve been looking for!

Not only is this app super cute, it‚Äôs so easy to use! I love the simplicity of it and how customizable it is to fit everyone‚Äôs unique tasks, goals or habits as they came them in the app. I tried a few other apps and in comparison I found that Avocation really motivated me to stay on track and organize my daily habits so I can accomplish them easily. Plus, the cute characters make it fun! My favorite thing about the app is the creative freedom they give by letting you customize your habit entirely with your own title, color, days of the week and time of day.

I would highly recommend! You can download the app for free to try it out and see how you like it. It limits how much you can do in the free experience but honesty, it‚Äôs worth the $10 (one time purchase for lifetime benefits) to not only get all the features of this beautiful app but also support the creators who clearly are making this app to help others. A one time payment for all the benefits of the app?? It‚Äôs very affordable and generous of the creators! Most apps I tried will charge you monthly or yearly!

One suggestion I‚Äôd like to make: It would be awesome if the habits were organizable! I love that they are separated by morning, afternoon and evening but currently the habits in each section stay in order by creation. So it would be nice to have a filter option to sort them by specific time, type of habit or importance or to be able to drag the habit bubbles to be in a custom desired order.

author: SpontaneousCreation

title: Tiimo: AI Planner & To-do
content:
I don‚Äôt need a fresh new glow up, or a new icon. I don‚Äôt need AI task management. 
I DO NEED the app to load when I open it on the first try. And I really need those features that made this app so awesome that I decided to purchase a lifetime membership. The routines, the ability to set a duration of time and then set the end time and the app would automatically set the start time. THAT is precisely what my neurodivergent brain NEEDS and that is exactly what I paid for. But it was taken away I keep waiting for them to bring it back but instead they keep adding things that I don‚Äôt need. I don‚Äôt need to see HIGH, MEDIUM, and LOW on the To-Do list. Or at least give the ability to turn those off, it‚Äôs very distracting. 
Ohhh, and I doesn‚Äôt sync across devices, you have to load each calendar for each device. 
The only thing I use is the Focus Timer so I can visually see how much time I have left (mostly getting ready to go somewhere) and this only works if I‚Äôve done the math correctly to begin with because that‚Äôs one of the features that were taken away. Ohhh how I wish I could get my money back!!! 

My previous review Aug 10, 2025:
DON‚ÄôT WASTE YOUR MONEY!!! 

It‚Äôs been a little over three months since I wrote my original review and nothing has improved. I am beyond frustrated because this app no longer has the features that made me decide to fork over $59! I don‚Äôt need or want AI, I want to be able to plan my day with routines (no longer a feature) and to reverse plan my day (also no longer available). They say they‚Äôre ‚Äúcommitted to supporting executive functioning and daily planning in the best possible way‚Äù but all I see them committed to is taking people‚Äôs money. And yes, there is a weekly/monthly overview on the web planner but it only shows events that are directly in your iCal or Google calendar, and if you are subscribed to other calendars, they don‚Äôt show up on the web planner. So the web planner is basically useless. Bottom line; DON‚ÄôT WASTE YOUR MONEY!!!

My previous review May 6, 2025:
Used to be perfect, now it‚Äôs just a mess.

Well, close to perfect. I paid the lifetime fee for this app and I wasted my money! I used to be able to do reverse scheduling; my appointment is at 1:15, I like to give myself 15 minutes arrival time to park and get inside so I would set the task for 15 min duration and the end time for 1:25 and the app would automatically set the start time. Same for travel time, 40 minutes to get there, set duration then the end time and app would set the start time. I‚Äôd plan my whole day this way. BUT now this feature is no longer there. I have to do the time math myself and if I‚Äôm wrong I could be late. I love the visual timer but it‚Äôs useless to me if I‚Äôm not on time. The main reason I purchased this VERY EXPENSIVE app was for the task duration and ability to plan my day backwards. 

There are many more features that would improve this app like the ability to glance at the week, or drag/drop multiple tasks when an appointment gets rescheduled, the ability to leave a comment (not a note) in the task, but I could (and did) live without these things. HOWEVER, I NEED the task duration returned!!!!

I don‚Äôt understand WHY features that were there when we PAID for the app would be removed.
author: Catrerry

title: Tiimo: AI Planner & To-do
content: beautiful app, i love the way it's designed. very streamline and accessible for those who cannot pay a subscription. thank you!
author: lumwahora

title: Tiimo: AI Planner & To-do
content: I can‚Äôt express what Tiimo is to me as an app and the degree to which it has changed my life. I encourage every neurodivergent person I know to try it. I have struggled my entire life with time blindness and staying current with my self care routines. I am a person who desperately needs routines to function but has trouble maintaining them. I built my routines into the app and add them to my schedule daily and it helps me figure out more than any other tool I‚Äôve tried how to carve out that time for myself. I also am able to create much more realistic goals for myself because it forces me to think about how much time things actually take. Setting realistic goals and not over scheduling myself has lead to a greater sense of accomplishment that in turn encourages me to accomplish more. I also have been more on time to things than I have ever been. I end every day with the review function and plan out the next day. It helps me so much with the paralysis I‚Äôve always felt when deciding what to do and what is most important to prioritize. Also, this app is created by the most incredible team. They are not just pumping this app out here- they legitimately deeply care about their mission to create a productivity app for neurodivergent people. I heard about an upcoming feature change that I used heavily and was concerned. I sent them a loooong email not expecting to hear back. They not only responded but helped me to understand the change and work through what it would mean for me. They went above and beyond to help me feel comfortable (because as we know, neurodivergent people can struggle with change.) They are ALWAYS there to help when you need assistance with the app and they do so with genuine compassion, care, and kindness.

author: Jrok707

title: Tiimo: AI Planner & To-do
content:
I‚Äôve been using Tiimo for over a year now, and I have to say the updates since my last review have been really great. A lot of the things I mentioned before actually feel like they were taken into consideration.

What I love most is that the app keeps its simplicity, but still allows for creativity. I can customize my layout to fit my style without feeling overwhelmed by too many options. The built-in color schemes are vibrant without being ‚Äútoo much,‚Äù which makes it fun and motivating to use.

I especially appreciate how the day is divided into morning, day, and evening sections, which keeps things from feeling cluttered. The drop-down lists are another favorite‚Äîbeing able to expand or shorten them makes my schedule feel manageable.

One of the biggest highlights for me has been the new AI integration. I actually suggested this in my original review, so seeing it added was amazing! It‚Äôs still new and could be expanded, but it‚Äôs already a great feature that makes planning easier.

Since these updates, I‚Äôve been using Tiimo more consistently, and I can honestly say it helps me stay on track throughout the day.

A few things I‚Äôd love to see in the future:
	‚Ä¢	More adaptations to the AI features.
	‚Ä¢	A true home screen view‚Äîbeing able to see tasks and check them off directly from my home screen without fully opening the app would be so helpful.
	‚Ä¢	A way to schedule travel time between activities, so that ‚Äúempty space‚Äù actually reflects the time I spend driving or transitioning, not just free time.

Overall, Tiimo is still my favorite ADHD/autism-friendly planner. It‚Äôs colorful, simple, and motivating, and I can see it only getting better from here.
author: Ciera.Johnson3

title: Tiimo: AI Planner & To-do
content: This app has been so helpful for me. I don‚Äôt have ADHD, but I am pretty forgetful, so creating my routines helps me not only stay on track but remember everything I have to do. I think the paid version is worth it, and I needed the paid version to create custom repeats for events. Speaking of that, there‚Äôs a weird glitch when creating repeats where the day that you select doesn‚Äôt align with the day that it creates the repeated event. Either some trial and error I figured out which day is which. There are some other minor glitches, but overall this is exactly what I was looking for. author: Touchlander123

title: Tiimo: AI Planner & To-do
content:
I didn‚Äôt think that any productivity app could help put me on a path that would lead to my dreams coming true. Yet the techniques and lessons I learned from using Tiimo have helped me to build the skills in such a way that I now do most thing out of habit and need the app less and less. 

That right there is pure magic and should be the point of all apps that are focused on helping people become more organized and especially when they are designed as thoughtfully as Tiimo; with the neurodivergent community in mind. Don‚Äôt miss out on the videos and how to tools in the app as they can really teach you things you thought you knew but really could benefit from learning more about. 

I found myself more successful in using Tiimo due to some of the quality of life perks such as the ability to utilize colors and emojis in interface that make it easier for my brain to sort and process the information it is seeing.

It‚Äôs essential features like this that help set Tiimo apart from the rest. I also very much appreciate the ability to have multiple profiles. As someone with multiple disabilities and varying needs in my day to day life, I value being able to switch profiles so that I can access different sets of daily tasks.

Not every productivity or organizational app is for everyone, but the flexibility provided by Tiimo means that I‚Äôm confident you‚Äôll find something beneficial from giving it a download and trial run. Good luck and enjoy your Adventures in the Apple App Store!

title: Joon: Kids ADHD Chore Tracker
content:
1. Heads up: unless you are going to assign 7 or fewer tasks per day, don't bother downloading this. The app strings you along and lets you believe you'll be able to use its basics for free. It DOES pester you nonstop to upgrade/subscribe, but you can opt out initially. You get this all set up, the kid's game app installed, and your kid invested in using it, and THEN after the 7th completed task, it hits you with the subscription requirement to keep using it. Very aggravated at the old bait and switch tactics and will be uninstalling. 
2. Additionally: For an app that is supposed to help keep a kid on track, why on earth are there a myriad of extra coin-earning tasks built in that keep the kid indefinitely on the app doing random things instead of helping them focus on executing the tasks assigned by the parent? Talk about a backfire.

author: Mariboza73

title: Joon: Kids ADHD Chore Tracker
content:
If you‚Äôre a parent looking for a fun, engaging, and productive way to help your child stay on top of daily tasks and build better habits, the Joon Kid App is a must-try. This app turns to-do lists into an interactive game where kids take care of a virtual pet called a ‚ÄúDoter,‚Äù and every real-world task they complete helps their pet grow and thrive.

What I loved:
	‚Ä¢	Gamified Motivation: The game-like approach makes chores and routines exciting. My child actually looks forward to brushing teeth or doing homework just to earn rewards in the app.
	‚Ä¢	Parental Controls: The parent dashboard is easy to use and allows me to assign tasks, monitor progress, and approve completed activities.
	‚Ä¢	Positive Reinforcement: Instead of constant reminders, my child now feels ownership over their daily responsibilities. The app rewards consistency, effort, and good habits.
	‚Ä¢	Educational Angle: It subtly encourages time management, independence, and goal-setting skills.

What could improve:
	‚Ä¢	Some customization options are limited (e.g., not all tasks are editable in detail).
	‚Ä¢	It‚Äôs more effective for younger kids (around ages 5-7); older children might find it less appealing.
	‚Ä¢	There‚Äôs a subscription cost, which may not work for every family‚Äôs budget‚Äîbut there is a free trial to test it out.

Overall Rating: 4.9/5

Joon isn‚Äôt just another kids‚Äô app‚Äîit‚Äôs a clever way to turn parenting into teamwork. If you‚Äôve struggled to get your child to stick to routines, this might be the help you‚Äôve been looking for.

I introduced the app to my daily routine and efforts to solidify healthy beneficial habits into my life. 
I have used several self-help books, Ytube videos, ,meditation and was having trouble hitting my stride to create this balance in my life between enjoyment, improvement, and recreation. 

Using this app has helped me make the skills and habits I wish to include in my day to day obvious, and easily accessible. 

The ease of integration, and set up allow for you to hit the ground running if you already have a great routine, or develop your routine for the long term.

I wish more things in life were as easy as this app.

I am just a teen and have never had kids so if I had a kid struggling I would hear them out about what there struggling with instead of hopping to conclusions and blame the phone and treat them like toddlers because they have a problem completely out of their control. To the parents who just want to keep their kids safe please avoid this app and just go through their device because I promise that you don‚Äôt need to know every single message or exactly the amount of time they have been on a app. Let the child have the privacy that they deserve. author: ECHass

title: Qustodio Parental Control App
content:
Pro:
Easy and quick to install on devices, also doesn‚Äôt show the install icon or app on any of the devices.
Accurate, detailed and quick updates sent to the parents instantly. 
App is fairly easy to navigate. 

Cons:
There should be separate restrictions for each device under each child. For example: I had to create an entire different profile for the children‚Äôs school computers to block all gaming and YouTube, whereas their phones and gaming computers have different rules, obviously. 

The section for ‚Äù daily time limit‚Äù simply doesn‚Äôt work.  It may block the internet and say ‚Äútime is up‚Äù but it doesn‚Äôt block my son playing fortnite or Roblox on his gaming PC because technically their Microsoft apps, same with the internet ‚Äúinstant freeze‚Äù option - it does not stop his internet for the gaming on his PC, only the internet browser so that‚Äôs basically useless. The ONLY feature that seems to work well is the restricted time grid, this completely locks them out of their devices. HOWEVER, this causes a problem with their iPhones, and using WhatsApp for emergencies so I then need to create a separate profile for their iPhones.  As it sits, each child has their own profile and then they have a profile for their iPhones and a profile for their school devices, this is silly - you should be able to create custom rules for each device linked to the child profile, not a blanket profile for all devices. With their iPhones the parental settings included with your Apple ID function much easier than this app, so just use that for their iPhones unless you want to see exactly what they‚Äôre using their phone for, then this app is your spy.  

Lastly, my one child‚Äôs profile shows she is constantly online, it shows her time usage as 24 hours a day - even when her device is off, so there must be some bugs to work out. I contacted support and have yet to hear back.

title: InnerNow: Meditation & Joy
content:
The way the app is organized is rather disappointing. While Chopra undoubtedly has several wonderful meditation series that can be purchased, once you purchase them, to use them on the app, you are forced to scroll all the way to the bottom of your home page, traveling through the next items that chopra is trying to sell you!  It would be much better to allow easy access the things you already purchased and place them at the top of the homepage. The Mission of Chopra and the Chopra Center is honorable; however, the developers of the Chopra app are not client focused, they simply want to sell you more stuff! There is room for significant improvement with some very minor changes by simply coming from a customer service focused frame of mind. The simple question should be asked, what could benefit the customer the most? Rather than the curtain frame of mind, which is, ‚Äúwhat can we sell them next?‚Äù

Enlightenment starts with leading by example and I encourage the Chopra app design staff to listen to what Chopra teaches, so they can do a better job on future app design updates. 

Lead by example. üôèüòä

Warm Regards,

James

title: InnerNow: Meditation & Joy
content: As a meditation coach, the Chopra: Meditation & Wellbeing app is the only app I recommend for my students. Compared to others, it is easy to navigate, personalized, and is designed aesthetically to induce calmness. Meditations range from beginners (5 minutes or so) to longer, more insightful sessions (20-60 mins). There are meditations with no sound, with music (binaural beats, solfeggio, sound baths, etc.), guided meditations, breathwork techniques and more! My favorite new addition is the ‚ÄúMonthly Vedic Astrology‚Äù.
author: MissileMS

title: InnerNow: Meditation & Joy
content:
Been a purchaser of the 21 day meditations and a follower of Chopra. This app is buggy-buggy to a frustrating point that in truth, seems to defeat the purpose of meditating.

Here‚Äôs what you will encounter:
Not many meditations with Chopra.

App will forget you are a subscriber and lock you out frequently. (Keep refreshing the app to solve)

App won‚Äôt remember your last ‚Äúplace‚Äù in a series.
(I‚Äôve had it for 4 months and it is stuck on what I did on day 2 of usage.)

Sometimes the app will take your subscription $$ but still not allow you in. (Contact customer service and eventually they will say to reinstall the app.)

Your prior purchases won‚Äôt be in the app. You will be directed to the website to listen to those.

Searching for anything is difficult and not at all designed intuitively.

Your choice. Insight Timer has none of these issues. I come to Chopra for a different vibe every once in a while and keep the frustration to a minimum.

Last note: several of these issues have been going on for 2 years or more per other reviews, with promises to fix. Just remember to ‚Äústay peaceful in your core‚Äù and I suggest the mantra ‚ÄúOm‚Äù for the familiar ‚Äúsomething went wrong‚Äù message.

author: Disneyfan9

title: Purity - Porn Block Browser
content:
I have long said ‚ÄúIf only there was a text-only browser for mobile!‚Äù Well, here it is. It gives you a black- and white-list option, as well as the option to add the email of an accountability partner, and a 4-digit pin to lock the settings. It does not take screenshots of your phone, but analyzes the text of your search words and of the web pages for risky/dangerous behavior.

And it works. Sometimes a little too well- for example, it will block some Intuit pages because they include the phrase ‚Äúyandex‚Äù. But by and large I can get done what I need done. Thankful to these folks for enabling me to have access to the internet for research and work, without the temptation of porn, or even of reading sensual stories. 

To Purity - thank you. Please don‚Äôt cave to the inevitable pressure of users who say ‚Äúthis would be perfect, if only we could also do X, Y, or Z‚Äù. The world needs a barebones text-based browser just like Purity is now. I get that some changes might be good, but you have a simple app that works. More complexity lends itself to more bugs and issues. 

To other users - this app works really well in tandem with the Screen Time restrictions on iPhones, if you want to really dial in safety on your phone. Set your safety settings in Purity and Screen Time, then have a trusted friend/accountability partner set the 4-digit pins for both Purity and Screen Time.

3 cheers to helping make the internet a safer place.

author: Eazyhoskglakfo

title: Purity - Porn Block Browser
content:
This app is great for resisting temptation, it will block URLs that you blacklist and any specific words you want blacklisted in URLs. It is in Google Safe Search by default and is great for blocking very specific sites or searches in specific sites. This is great and has been very helpful.

The positives sadly stop there. This browser is slow and very clunky, taking a considerable amount of time to load web pages even on a newer phone with great connection. The main issue though, is that if you have a specific URL blacklisted, it will block that URL even if it is a back link somewhere on the page. For example, if I have Twitter blocked, it will load a web page until it realizes there is a link for a company‚Äôs Twitter account somewhere on the page, then it will send an alert and stop loading the page. This app and its blocking algorithm does not take into account URLs that are linked to a web page, it just sees them and automatically blocks the page. You can imagine how frustrating it is to try and load a web page but it is blocked because the author has a link to their social media at the bottom of the page.

Although this app will help you fight temptation and that is the ultimate goal, it is slow, filled with errors like the example given above, and poorly optimized. I am actively looking for a replacement because of these issues.

author: Odkool

title: Purity - Porn Block Browser
content:
No content blocker is perfect‚Äî there‚Äôs almost always a workaround. We tend to find what we‚Äôre after if we look hard enough. Chances are, if you‚Äôve been in the fight for years or decades now, you know plenty of terms and websites that may let you sneak past security. That being said, Purity does a great job at putting up tough borders. The option to whitelist/blacklist terms and sites is so welcome; having an accountability partner option is also welcome; being able to report pages, block pages as you come across them, block images and videos entirely, and more, make this an incredibly useful app for protecting your heart. So I can say pretty confidently that I would recommend this app.

I also want to say to anyone reading this review that fighting temptation is an arduous process, and frequent victory over it may take a lot longer than you expected. You may find, as I have, that the issue goes deep, and you might have to cut out other things from your life beside just porn‚Äî other apps, websites, games, shows, movies, books... Things that may seem innocent enough, or innocuous, but tempt you to make the wrong choice.

In the Bible, in Matthew 5:30, Jesus says that if your right hand causes you to sin you should cut it off. He doesn‚Äôt mean literally (or Christians all across the world would be distinguishable by how maimed they are!) but he‚Äôs using a very extreme kind of imagery and language to describe the severity of action needed to overcome a sinful lifestyle. He‚Äôs saying, ‚ÄúIf that show you like leads you to desire porn, stop watching it. Get rid of it. Rip it up from the root. If that app or game makes you lust, delete it, prevent yourself from even having access to it. Whatever tempts you, cut it out like its a cancerous mass or it will eventually kill you.‚Äù

This app will help you do that. It will help you be proactive in the fight, not just reactive. It is a handy tool in the task of uprooting bad habits in your life. And for those burdened by the guilt and shame that come with the struggle with porn, I say, ‚ÄúLay that burden down at the cross of Jesus.‚Äù If we own our sin and admit our guilt, God will consistently and reliably forgive us of that sin and work in our hearts to purge those habits from our lives. (1 John 1:9) And He does that with joy, because Jesus paid the price for our guilt when he sacrificed himself in our place. God sees the finished work of Jesus‚Äî the atoning blood spilled to pay our debt and the blameless righteousness of the perfect Son‚Äî and He delights to take away your shame because you‚Äôve been justified. To use this app is to lean into the change that God is already working in your heart, and will see to it‚Äôs end; it is to be that much more in step with living a guilt-free life.

author: SoraDW

title: Awesome Habits: Habit Tracker
content: You can set up any number of daily, weekly or monthly habits to track, and can also put them into custom‚Äìnamed categories. I like that the main screen with the habits being tracked also displays a percentage of completion, which can count either your daily tasks, or all tasks via one of the settings. And the percentage of completion doesn‚Äôt seem to be an All-or-Nothing situation. For example, if a habit needs a count of seven to complete and you have only performed it four times, you get credit for that. Nice. You can activate a setting that moves completed Habits to the bottom of the daily/weekly/monthly list, so you can concentrate on the ones that aren‚Äôt completed. Overall, I think this is a really good app!
author: GeneW1967

title: Awesome Habits: Habit Tracker
content:
The app works really well! Enjoying it. 

Would love the following features:

1. All me to make a goal out of any Apple health metric, I don't think you need to build them all in, but rather just a section within the "custom habit" to pick a health stat so that it can automatically connect to that health data. 
2. An "On or Off Track" status indicator for the habits that are weekly or monthly as well as one for the daily status. In other words if my status is weekly, but it's tracking sugar intake, I really have no idea if I'm on track with my goal or not which forces me to to some math in my head "ok we're halfway through the week and it looks like I'm less than halfway done so I should work on this today" rather than seeing the gap between where I should be and where I am, or inverse, the fact that I can ignore that habit today because I'm already ahead. Without this feature it makes weekly and monthly goals difficult to achieve.
author: MatthiasIam

title: Awesome Habits: Habit Tracker
content: Best habit tracking app I‚Äôve ever used, and I‚Äôve tried a ton of them. Interface easy to understand and yet with all the options and stats you need. Widgets very customizable. Another feature that makes this app outstanding and that other apps don‚Äôt give to much attention is the ton of icons you can choose from for your habits. You can make lists to organize your habits and see the stats by list, even have an app intertwined in other categories not only one. Another aspect that I liked about the app is that when checking the history of a habit the app is designed in a way that it doesn‚Äôt allow to accidentally modify past days, if you want to change something in the history you have to be intentional, there‚Äôs not risk of changing the history by error with the finger like in other apps. The only feature I would add is the ability to choose how many days in a week I want to track an app by quantity and not only by choosing selected weekdays like ‚ÄúMonday, Tuesday, etc‚Äù. I‚Äôm surprised that this app is not yet as famous as others. Ratings are great, must be only a matter of marketing. Worth every penny I paid to be a premium member, just hope that as this app grows the developers will remember my lifetime subscription because I‚Äôve had bad experiences with apps in which I was already a lifetime member but they start charging monthly subscriptions and forget about their old offer they made with old members that were here from the beginning and apply their new terms on them too. I hope this is not the case. Keep up the good work!
author: Israel Hopkins

title: Awesome Habits: Habit Tracker
content: Loving the simplicity so far. The free version gives you 3 habits to track, which is plenty for most people. I normally don‚Äôt like purchasing apps, but I‚Äôm enjoying the full capabilities and statistics it gives to help me keep my daily goals going so it‚Äôs well worth it for $1.99 a month (even cheaper if you just purchase for the year or lifetime).
author: itsjuststeph.

title: Awesome Habits: Habit Tracker
content:
A lot of thought went into this app and it shows. So easy to use and a pleasant experience to mark goals complete. Tap the widget, tap the goal, and done. Or use Siri Shortcuts. This is perfect.

I was wondering if you have a roadmap anywhere on what improvements might be coming down the pipe. Some apps have an entire week view with little colored or uncolered squares showing if a goal was completed. It‚Äôs a cool way to pack a lot of data, like 10 goals over a week, and view it all at once.

Another cool feature would be multi level goals to track workouts, like the habit could be bench press, the # of reps would another dimension, and the weight would be the 3rd level dimension. Getting data in for weight and reps would mean you completed the goal of bench press, but would be cool to track weight and reps in a way that could be displayed on graphs. So not just using the notes feature for this.

Lastly, for the hardcore nerds among us, csv export of all the data in case we want to juxtapose our goals alongside data from other apps that we are tracking. Like overlaying our goals data on a graph from our smart scale app that shows our weight/ muscle mass/etc. exporting the data makes this possible and allows for the potential to make some amazing insights on how our habits can correlate to other things that we are tracking.

This app should become the solution to track everything else. We have Apple Watch and smart scales to track so many things, overlaying that data on top of anything else we want to track should make this a must have app.

title: Awesome Habits: Habit Tracker

content:
Is the app good? Absolutely ‚Äî 100%.
I‚Äôve been using this app for over two years, and it‚Äôs been such a valuable tool that I‚Äôve recommended it to my family as well. It‚Äôs genuinely helped me stay focused, and I‚Äôve always felt it was worth paying for.

That said, I‚Äôve noticed some recent changes that feel a bit disappointing. For example, we used to have access to strict mode for an entire day, and unlimited app blocking, which was incredibly helpful. Now, strict mode is capped at 12 hours, and the block sessions are limited to 4 hours, which feels restrictive ‚Äî especially for those of us who rely on the app for long, focused periods.

I completely understand that you need to monetize ‚Äî no offense at all ‚Äî but I do wish the app would return to the features that originally made it feel generous and user-focused. These changes feel like a step backward in terms of flexibility.

Still, I truly believe the app is a great investment. I just hope the team can find a balance between revenue and retaining the features that long-time users loved.
author: StrawberryMochi üçìüç°

author: Why-not-working

title: AppBlock: Block Apps & Website
content:
This app is definitely better than any of the other apps I've tried on iphone. Every other one I could beat quickly so it wasn't even worth it. This one, I can't beat the strict mode. Which is what I need. I'm hopelessly inept at controlling my doom scrolling. It's been like this for years. I used to be an Android user, though, and the app I used on Android had way more flexibility with the controls and could be way stricter. 

I also loved the feature to charge $$ you for use on Android. I would like to lock down nearly everything all the time on my iphone, but I can't - strict mode has alerted me several times that I can't do that bc then my phone would be in strict mode the whole time. Well duh, that's the point. The android option allowed me to bypass, though,  any app block setting for a fee I'd set. So I'd use it in an emergency or one time use need. It was pretty slick. Money def deters me. 

Also, the location controls were better. I could set the location so precisely that the lunch room at my office was clear of the app blocks. And I could set 5 minute breaks at the top of the hour on all scheduled app blocks. Really nice if you're having a conversation on Instagram. That way I'd still be able to maintain a functioning conversation with my bff (Instagram disappear mode is critical) but still be able to focus on work. 

All food for thought for the developers!

Definitely recommend this app!

title: AppBlock: Block Apps & Website
content:
This app worked well enough in its free version that I went ahead and bought premium. It seemed to do great for about two days and then suddenly I was able to fully access all my blocked apps, during the time they should have been blocked. Not just cached material, either‚Äîfull access to everything, phone overriding the app and rendering it completely useless. 

The only way to make it work again is to disable the schedule and then re-enable it, which somehow reactivates the restrictions. Sometimes I have the self-control to do this and sometimes not. But I had been considering putting this on my kids‚Äô devices, and now I know there is no point‚Äîthey won‚Äôt voluntarily turn it on when it stops working. 

I have read that Apple makes it extremely hard for 3rd party apps to have any control over your use, so I assume there‚Äôs just some kind of glitch between AppBlock and iOS. Four stars because when this thing works, it works fine; one off because it doesn‚Äôt work consistently.

author: Swaggy_boy04

title: AppBlock: Block Apps & Website
content:
The free version wasn‚Äôt as strict as I would‚Äôve like it to be, so I ended up going premium for $15 for the first year (still in that first year). 

 While creating different schedules are nice, I‚Äôve learned that there‚Äôs only one ‚Äústrict block‚Äù option‚Äî the schedules block‚Äî that really works. While it‚Äôs been helpful to keep me off my phone endlessly in the morning and at night, I created another limit to control how much time I‚Äôm allowed on an app (ex: ‚ÄúI want to spend 30 minutes on Instagram max.‚Äù), but it won‚Äôt allow me to put that schedule in strict mode. So it‚Äôs practically useless, since I can pause it at any time. 

 Additionally, say I was to go into one of my schedules I‚Äôve made and add a new app. If I add it to the list of apps within the schedule, if I go to save my changes, I‚Äôm given a notification that says, ‚Äúchanges can‚Äôt be made, or apps would be blocked indefinitely.‚Äù So just by adding a new app‚Äî which, for premium should be unlimited addition of apps‚Äî my schedule won‚Äôt let me change anything. 
 I‚Äôm sure I could loophole it by deleting the schedule entirely and creating it again with the new app, but it shouldn‚Äôt have to be that difficult. 

 They created a ‚Äúhide the pause‚Äù button, in hopes for you to be unable to keep hitting ‚Äúpause for 15 minutes‚Äù for hours (guilty), but there‚Äôs nothing keeping you from simply going to setting and clicking ‚Äúshow pause button.‚Äù So, even in that update, it‚Äôs not helpful. 

 They asked once for feedback, and I happily gave it‚Äî not out of frustration but truly wanting to give the developer honest feedback‚Äî but there‚Äôs no space to leave your feedback in the app unless it‚Äôs asked for. So, reviews were the only way to go. 

 I would love to see this app succeed, but I‚Äôm struggling to stay without any updates.

author: hindman mount

title: MyRoutine: Routine Habit Goal
content: Life changing! I originally downloaded this app to build habits. Checking each habit I‚Äôve completed feels so satisfying. It‚Äôs that small sense of pride that keeps you going. No matter how small that change seems, when you incorporate into your everyday life, it makes a difference. This app gives me an excuse to not skip out on small tasks from flossing to getting ahead of my assignments. The functions could be a bit smoother and the emoji keyboard has a small scrolling back-and-forth bug, but this app still does its job and completes its purpose well. The thing I love most about this app is how you can build a series of routines and have a timer for each of them. If you take too long, then the timer will turn red and begin to count your overtime. That has shown me when I surprisingly take too long on something that I didn‚Äôt think was a problem. Best of all, you have the option to make habits repeat between certain weekdays or a number of times a week, and if you do finish something that was a goal, you can mark it off forever. For example, when I got my braces off today, I could mark my habit of wearing elastics as forever completed. :) Something this app could change is seeing progress as ‚Äúlast 7 days‚Äù or ‚Äúlast 30 days‚Äù instead of ‚Äúthis week‚Äù or ‚Äúthis month‚Äù. Because when you just started a month, there‚Äôs not much to see with ‚Äúthis month,‚Äù and that forces me to scroll back to see my progress from last month, which is less efficient.

title: MyRoutine: Routine Habit Goal
content:
I‚Äôve tried more than a few routine-building apps and this is by far the one closest to what I‚Äôve always wanted in one of these. First of all‚Äî NO TIMER (or at least the option to turn it off.) Timers have always been a source of stress in my routines because I can‚Äôt always stick to whatever I‚Äôve assigned a habit. Secondly‚Äî the LOOK! I‚Äôm a spreadsheet girl, plain and simple as that. The customization is always fun too. And finally‚Äî the routines themselves! content: I found this app in the middle of Bar Prep when I really needed to hone in on what I was studying and for how long. I would also like to say how amazing it is to have a developer so passionate about the app he created. The discord channel is amazing to figure out unknown features and to ask questions. author: Dan_1313

title: Focused Work - Pomodoro Timer
content:
This app checks several of the boxes I‚Äôm looking for in a pomodoro system. Though, I can‚Äôt bring myself to use this app or pay for the subscription as it‚Äôs incredibly ugly. It needs a substantial UI upgrade. Very off-putting colors, constrained menus, odd layouts, etc. The entire experience needs to be more minimal while maintaining functionality. What‚Äôs worse, is there isn‚Äôt a single setting to alter any part of the app‚Äôs appearance, which is a very odd decision on the developers part. 

For instance, the green and orange glowing icons on the session structure screen. Yikes. That along with the ugly, bold purple core app color is just terrible. I also don‚Äôt understand why integrations is mentioned on this screen, it‚Äôs already in settings. There‚Äôs also a glitchy Siri thing at the bottom that is spazzing out. It‚Äôs unfortunate because having a session view screen like this that breaks down and labels each section of the pomodoro system isn‚Äôt available in other apps that I‚Äôm aware of. And it‚Äôs a bit ruined by the ugliness of it all. 

Also the tiny icons above the pomodoro timer wrapped in a bold red line. Why?? This is so weird. The entire top of the app is so cluttered and strange. And the bold red, uneditable color of the timer is not cool. And again, why is integrations on a tiny system menu icon that‚Äôs just cluttering up the limited space available? Integrations should be in settings and left alone. Makes absolutely no sense to keep pushing integrations. If someone wanted to use the functionality, they will‚Ä¶ in settings. 

You also can‚Äôt remove the dumb tomato icon in front of pomodoro. Some of your users are over 12 and don‚Äôt want to use emojis. Weird thing to hardcode.

Under appearance settings, where you‚Äôre weirdly only able to edit the font thickness (seriously), it even shows a purple timer color and yet the only available color on the actual main screen is VERY red. 

We also don‚Äôt need the ‚Äúready to focus?‚Äù text. Yes, we‚Äôre ready to focus, that‚Äôs why we downloaded a focus app. 

This isn‚Äôt to say that other pomodoro apps are much better, though some apps with limited functionality have a much better UI.

This app has a lot going for it, but as a person who shys away from ugly apps, I just can‚Äôt bring myself to use it. But I do see a lot of potential here, so I‚Äôll check back to see if UI improvements are made.

Also, in the middle of a session I tend to get a noise and a dumb message basically telling me to focus that I need to clear out while I'm in the middle of working on something for a client and I have to divert my attention... I wish there was a way to turn that off.

author: Justace23

title: Focused Work - Pomodoro Timer
content:
As productivity tools go‚Äîespecially for those who use Toggl and want to integrate time-tracking‚ÄîFocused Work is probably the strongest. Add to that the ability to integrate Shortcuts and it becomes a powerful tool with a lot of flexibility and potential. 

However, although it boasts many strengths, it does still have one (admittedly, superficial/minor) flaw: The emojis are non-negotiable. For all its flexibility, not having the option to opt out of using emojis‚Äîespecially when they‚Äôre displayed so prominently‚Äîis incredibly distracting, and incentivizes me to hide what is otherwise a clean interface with crisp Live Activities. 

That‚Äôs not suggesting adding an alternative like SF Symbols; just that I wish the emojis themselves were optional, so I‚Äôm not required to use them or forced to decide which garish emoji best fits the custom focus session I want to create.  PLEASE make these optional.
author: tomc_23

title: Focused Work - Pomodoro Timer
content:
I spent a lot of time searching for an app with a flexible Pomodoro timer that includes a count-up clock and tracks my sessions. I love that Focused Work offers a Flowmodoro option, a flexible timer, and the traditional Pomodoro. The Toggl integration is also very convenient. This app has really boosted my productivity.

I knocked off one star because there are some features that I find extremely annoying. So much so that every now and then, I stop using the app, try to find something similar, but never find it, so I come back. The main issue is the notifications. I didn‚Äôt like them, so I turned them off. Now I get reminders to turn on notifications so that I can get reminders! It really makes no sense. Then there are the reminders to rate and review, which I guess worked. I also wish we could complete the session without having to pause it and that it had better sync between iPhone and MacBook

author: teavea013

title: Inflow - Manage your ADHD
content:
STAY AWAY 

I don‚Äôt usually write reviews. But this app inspired. 

You be assaulted by an endless stream of quizzes, that are very hard to focus through, and added, time consuming pointless graphics splash screens and glossy nothingness. Users are completely captive to this endless process, and it is extremely stressful for my adhd.  I devoted close to an hour trying to get into this app and became so frustrated I submitted a support request and detailed, fair and respectful feedback for them to approve. 

They didn‚Äôt reply to my message content, then they charged me $200, one week after downloading for a trial, and trying my best to communicate with the developers about my situation and asking for help. 

Stay away from this app. It was developed by developers, for developers, without an understanding of what adhd users will actually think and feel. This app will profit off us, inappropriately, because adhders are particularly susceptible to bait and switch predatory pricing tactics. We already had an adhd tax, we don‚Äôt need Trojan horse solutions making the situation worse. 

STAY AWAY

content: I just started the 7 day trial and I am excited to see how this turns out. So far the app has been both validating and informative. I have struggled severely with my ADHD for the last couple of years. I don‚Äôt know if it has anything to do with the fact that I stopped drinking alcohol or that I am just more engaged in the world due to work and responsibilities but either way I feel like this app is just what I‚Äôve been needing. It‚Äôs practical, helpful, and very supportive. Thank you Inflow team! Will be posting updates as I continue with my free trial
author: RogueRavenKing

title: Inflow - Manage your ADHD
content:
Inflow has been, and continues to be very helpful for me.  I‚Äôve learned a lot through the modules.  

Having said that, the live/co-working events and the community forum are my favorite parts of Inflow.  The Sunday Setup is my most favorite, and integral to getting my week started off on the right foot.
author: LateBloomer592

title: Inflow - Manage your ADHD
content: I have gotten some gems from this app. However, I wish they would add more content more frequently and follow-up/dive deeper into things. It has been a great starting point for introducing concepts I‚Äôve never heard of. For instance, I just finished the relationship module and it introduced the idea of learning how you reestablish a sense of safety after a conflict vs your partner and communicating this so there is no misunderstanding. However, these ideas are introduced and dropped. It would be great to have more guided opportunities to engage with them so they stick better. I also wish it helped more with navigating time management, pressure of expectations, setting goals and social dynamics in the workplace, in different roles (ie boss vs middle manager vs entry level employee).

author: SmidtLicAc

title: Inflow - Manage your ADHD
content: Downloading this app is the worst decision if you think you might want to cancel in the future. I did the free trial and decided to try it out for a year, which was $200. After I was charged I realized I wasn‚Äôt using the app and it wasn‚Äôt worth the money for me. So I decided to cancel future subscriptions. However, when I went to my iPhone subscriptions under settings, the Inflow app wasn‚Äôt listed. I figured it wasn‚Äôt renewing and I wasn‚Äôt going to be charged again. Boy was I wrong!!!! I have been charged 2 years in a row after my initial purchase and cannot figure out how to cancel. This app is created for people with ADHD, so these experts should know that canceling subscriptions needs to be easy for its users because having to go through multiple steps to figure out how to cancel isn‚Äôt always possible. It‚Äôs my belief the app creator makes canceling this subscription difficult to impossible knowing very well that its users aren‚Äôt always capable of canceling, therefore they are able to bank on the very people they intend to help. I want my $400 back for the 2 years I was charged and I do not want to be charged for this next subscription coming up in the next couple weeks.

author: EESF

title: Inflow - Manage your ADHD
content: You know, in today‚Äôs ultra-monetized world, it‚Äôs hard to find something not tainted by the poison of mobile phone ads and useless currency. But to make me pay for my mental health with an outrageous fee of $17 a month, is pure and utter evil. When the toxicity of capitalized greed was just for mobile games and social media, that was fine. But when it spreads to therapy and mental health helpers, that should raise a few questions. If Wall Street expects me to pay $17 a month for something I have no control over, I won‚Äôt. This app says too bad to the people who can‚Äôt afford it, but need the help, leaving them rummage around the App Store for the help they need. What fat cat billionaire thinks people will pay $17 a month for help with a mental problem?! This app is  such proof that there is evil in the world, I‚Äôm surprised the app developer isn‚Äôt Satan himself. This is ridiculous, and I will not stand for it! Don‚Äôt get this app.

title: Betwixt‚ÄìThe Mental Health Game
content:
Now, I‚Äôm not saying this app is a replacement for therapy. But what I am saying is that the raw experiences I‚Äôve had in this app were better and more psychologically productive than any therapy session I‚Äôve been to in the past. This is just what I needed for how my brain works and its analytical and emotional side. I learned great things about myself, life, memories, self esteem, trauma, etc. Not to mention, this app is accessible. I couldn‚Äôt pay for it but really wished to continue the stories sense they were helping me, and so I signed up for a free account sponsored by someone else. I cannot fully express my tremendous gratitude for that feature. I have tremendous gratitude for this entire project, as I haven‚Äôt found anything else like it. I hope in the future there will be more, but for now I can take the lessons I‚Äôve learned and am one step closer to living my life to the fullest. 

Thank you.
author: Morgan Kate D.

title: Betwixt‚ÄìThe Mental Health Game
content:
I have only just started with the app, and it is lovely so far, but felt the need to comment now as this issue is really bothering me up front and keeping me from spending the time in the app that I need to.

I wish the developers would increase the font size a bit more, and consider making the font colors a bit darker when on a light background (or vice a versa ‚Ä¶ I haven‚Äôt gotten far enough in to know if there is later dark backgrounds with dark text), so that there is more contrast. 

It is a strain at the current size and light font color, which adds to headaches and stress, which is counterproductive to what the app is trying to do. I need to use the app right now, to try to reduce the bad headaches and tension I am feeling at this moment, and some of the anxiety and PTSD issues, but I cannot because of the eye strain. Just trying to read the text is adding to the headaches and tension, which is in itself causing anxiety. 

Or maybe the developers could build in some options for the user to set the font size and color, or tweak the contrast? 

There is no reason, with this being a text based experience, that the font size can‚Äôt be made more readable. I can‚Äôt be the only one who would like it to be easier on the eyes. I would up my rating to 5 stars if they did this! Please, please, please!!!

author: Traumantic

title: Betwixt‚ÄìThe Mental Health Game
content:
Real person, I promise, and if you read some of my other reviews I can be highly critical and sound like a Karen quite honestly. I wasn‚Äôt even looking for an app like this mental health wise or gaming wise. The types of videos I watch about having better mental health just kinda popped the ad for this app onto my screen.

I‚Äôve always enjoyed guided meditation along with choose your own adventure games. This app is the best of both worlds! It has peaceful music with therapeutic storyline and prompts or times where you can respond with your own entry. The ‚Äúnarrator‚Äù doesn‚Äôt speak so the voice that your mind comes up with to read their lines in is all up to your interpretation.

Now, I did get bummed at first upon realizing that there is a tiered payment system after the first 3 levels, however, do not let this run you away! It is only a one time payment! This is in order to help the company grow and it is not at all a money grab like most of the other apps out there! There are 3 different payments you can choose from to continue your journey and all of them are only a one time payment that unlocks everything at that tier permanently, the lowest of which I believe was $13.99 if I remember correctly. So they really do try to make it as affordable as possible. This is just a very small company that needs help in order to grow, so every penny helps.

There is such a creative and kind team behind the Betwixt App. As a player, you can tell that a lot of time and effort went into putting the resources together and creating the story mode adventure. Really great app and just what I never knew I needed!

I am a very in tune person when it comes to emotions and how my head work‚Äôs, but I‚Äôve learned so much from this, THEY ARE NOT PAYING ME TO SAY THIS! author: Lucy_Reviewed_This

title: ScreenZen- Screen Time Control
content:
I‚Äôve tried my fair share of screen time apps, and most of them left me frustrated‚Äîeither because of expensive subscriptions or because they weren‚Äôt effective enough. ScreenZen, however, has completely changed my perspective.

What makes it stand out to me is the thoughtful design. Instead of simply blocking apps, it gives you a customizable pop-up that asks if you really want to use one of your daily ‚Äúpasses.‚Äù That pause, that question, makes me think twice‚Äîand it works. On top of that, the app has a strict cut-off option for when I need firmer boundaries, which I appreciate.

But what impressed me most is their approach to cost. ScreenZen doesn‚Äôt demand a subscription. It‚Äôs available freely, with the option to support the developers through donations. For people like me who can‚Äôt afford to subscribe to dozens of apps (because of medical expenses, in my case), this is an absolute gift. And despite being donation-based, the service is excellent‚Äîbetter than many paid alternatives I‚Äôve tried.

In short, ScreenZen is simple, powerful, and accessible. If you‚Äôre looking for a screen time app that respects both your focus and your budget, I highly recommend it.

author: covegirl07

title: ScreenZen- Screen Time Control
content:
I am so thankful for this app. I know how apps and devices are DESIGNED to be addictive, to get us hooked. And I know myself, I know that I can get sucked into it. So I need to put limits beforehand because once my phone has my attention, it‚Äôs hard for me to think clearly and set a limit. I can lose track of time so easily!! I bet many feel the same. This app has been one of my main tools to keep me focused and block distractions. 

I still use my phone and apps, I just do it more intentionally now. For example, I only allow myself to open YouTube 5x per day, for 7 min each time. And when I want to open it, I have to solve some math problems. I have a time limit on safari and then after I reach that, I can only open it 5 more times. 

Also I made it so it I want to change the settings or if I want to disable the block one day, I have to open ScreenZen and wait a minute to even change anything. These are all functions I set up in ScreenZen. And you can choose your own functions/limits.

author: bear man70

title: Hush Nag Blocker
content: ### How Hush Works Hush is a content blocker for Safari that focuses on blocking nag screens, such as cookie consent banners and privacy-intrusive tracking scripts. It does this by using a set of rules that target specific scripts and elements on web pages without interacting directly with the site itself. ### Why It Might Be Less Effective Now 1. **Lack of Updates**: The Hush app and its GitHub project have not seen significant updates recently, which might mean it's not keeping up with new tracking techniques and ad implementations. 2. **Advanced Obfuscation**: Some websites employ advanced methods to bypass blockers, which Hush may not be updated to counter. 3. **Evolving Web Standards**: The web is constantly evolving, and without regular updates, any blocker may fall behind in its effectiveness. Checkout the developers GitHub page (found on the website) to see that it‚Äôs been inactive 4 years. Thank you Hush for the great service you provided, and I hope to see you again. But now we must find another.

content: Often doesn‚Äôt work. I feel it‚Äôs are only updated when the app is updated, not dynamically via url like so many others. And in those cases, this app actually prevents me from proceeding past the consent pop up. As for the description, it‚Äôs not really clear what this app is doing. there‚Äôs no documentation or much of any explanation of what‚Äôs going on behind-the-scenes. The only real source of anything is a GitHub link. and once you navigate around and find the developers biographical page or about me section, one of the first things I noticed was that he says he doesn‚Äôt have time to invest in his projects. So‚Ä¶. This isn‚Äôt a money-making tool. I get that. It would be nice to know upfront more about the app I‚Äôm downloading, how it works, how often it is or isn‚Äôt updated, etc. After looking around on the repository, I see that it is working very much the same way as Easylist and incorporates the fanboy list. author: Mnop0987

title: Migiri: Porn Blocker & More
content:
Just a heads up for future readers and potential users, $145 /year. No other payment plan options. That does NOT include therapist sessions which is an extra $60 /session. Free trial lasts a week. 

The blocker works well in browsers, but not integrated well enough to use in apps, contrary to what the app‚Äôs description states. Yes, you can block the website that the app pulls its data from, but that in turns blocks the entire app, regardless of the url you enter. A good example is Reddit. Reddit has lots of content, that includes porn; however, blocking Reddit.com, or even blocking specific NSFW communities, blocks the entire app. Not helpful. I still want to browse Reddit, but just with NSFW content blocked, and Migiri is not capable of this. 

The price tag was enough to turn me away. I think I speak for most when I say porn is watched due to depression, and depressed people don‚Äôt have $200+ to throw away on an app.
author: Chris22599

title: Migiri: Porn Blocker & More
content:
I'm still within my free trial of Migiri and seriously contemplating subscribing and buying the annual membership.

I first got Migiri and I was a little skeptical. I had tried other blockers and things, but the fact that Migiri focused or seemed to want to focus on MORE than just blocking, drew me to it.

Before I get on to talking about why I love the app, I will say that I wasn't pleased about not getting notifications from the app or my chosen companion getting emails to celebrate / cheer me on. 

I emailed the Migiri team about the issue and they responded quickly and a few days later, the issue was resolved. It means a lot to be that I, as a user, was treated respectfully, in a timely manner, and heard.

Now, going back to what i've enjoyed from Migiri... I loved that there were some lessons to help me contemplate my addiction and behaviors. I love that one of the lessons helped focus on accepting a relapse and doubling down on the commitment to quit.

I can't say for anyone else, but that lesson really helped me get to understand who I am, what I need, and why I relapse.

So yes, I would suggest this app to anyone who's trying to quit porn. A blocker isn't good enough because there is always a way to circumvent it if you look hard and long.

However, a blocker that also helps you change and grow so that you can some day not need a blocker so well worth the price.

As for all of y'all on this journey, you got this and keep at it. You're not alone and you do matter. I would suggest y'all get this app and also try groups, therapy, blockers, church, and friends.

Every positive relationship is another strand in the net to keep you from falling.
