author: N.V üíó

title: Focus Traveller - Flow Timer
content:
I recently switched to FocusTraveller from the Flora app, which I had used for years. It had become virtually unusable because of its glitches. 

I love the intuitive interface of the app, and the graphics are gorgeous. The prompt to take deep breaths are helpful. I love the ability to take breaks and choose your traveler. 

It would be great to see a few valuable features I enjoyed from other productivity apps. 

1. Adding a sense of progression to keep it engaging. In other apps, I liked how spending more time on the app allowed you to unlock new features, like growing new plant species or exploring new areas. It made the experience more rewarding and less monotonous. Introducing a similar gamification element here would be a fantastic addition and help keep users motivated- maybe adding different maps to explore or customization for your traveler (like clothes/accessories or a pet that travels with you). 

1.5: Special badges- the Flora app not only allowed users to unlock new plant species to grow as they spent more time focusing; they also gifted a badge for every plant that was grown either with a friend or through a paid session (putting money on the line). Seeing those badges was very rewarding, so even when I ran out of plants to unlock, I focused on earning both badges for every plant I had. Visual reinforcement for progression is KEY to keeping users interested in coming back to the app. 

2. Allowing users to put money on the line. Flora allowed users to choose a value (between $5-$100) to be charged if they took a break or left the app. This is useful for those who need an extra push to stay focused on their task- it helped me a LOT during finals season.

3. The ability to block distracting apps during the focus session. This adds an extra barrier to simply scrolling on social media while the session is running. I benefitted a LOT from this feature, as I sometimes open distracting apps without even thinking when I get bored. 

4. The ability to add friends without Game Center. I very, very frequently studied with friends through the Flora app. It provides an extra layer of accountability. Providing a QR code or a username to add friends through would be convenient. 

I have diagnosed ADHD, but these features kept me coming back to the Flora app for a little less than four years. I really love FocusTraveller and would love to see the aforementioned updates. I think they would enhance the experience and keep distracted users engaged and coming back for more. 

I hope these suggestions were helpful. Thanks for reading my review!

author: Jasonfeatme in Wuhan

title: Focus Traveller - Flow Timer
content: I have the *worst* time actually focusing on my work and staying off my phone. This is the first app where I can set it and it actually gets me to focus. The combination of the calming music and seeing my character climbing a mountain really helps me actually focus. I‚Äôve downloaded similar apps in the past, but they were too passive and were literally just timers to keep you off your phone. My brain will get always get itchy and I‚Äôll go back to my phone. I‚Äôve tried listening to just music, podcasts, having YouTube videos on in the background, just having silence, listening to white noise, NOTHING has stopped my brain from getting itchy and then going right back to my phone and losing focus and valuable work time. There‚Äôs something about watching the movement of my character that gives me a little focus boost. I have no idea why this app works as well as it does, but it does!!!! If you have problems focusing, give this a download. There‚Äôs a free version you can try to get a feel for it and if you want to get the premium version it‚Äôs a one time payment of $7.99 and you can use the premium features of the app for life! Well worth it and I LOVE LOVE that it‚Äôs not another subscription!!!
author: SopranoNut

title: Focus Traveller - Flow Timer
content:
I absolutely love this app! I have bad ADHD and it totally helped me focus! I got it originally to lock in when doing my school work and I got almost 72 hours of complete productivity over 2.5 weeks! I crushed my finals and now I‚Äôm graduating! I‚Äôll definitely be using this going forward to focus on language learning or other tasks as I felt it was super helpful!
I love that there is a one-time purchase option for the subscription as I love being able to pay outright if I want to use something! I actually ended up picking up the full version because I felt it helped me enough and I want to support the dev to keep supporting this app with new features! As a game dev myself I feel it‚Äôs very important to support the things you love!

Some features I‚Äôd love to see added: a Lock Screen widget, an Apple Watch app (please I would love to use this on my watch so I don‚Äôt have to always have my phone with me! It would increase my use of this 100x so I didn‚Äôt have to use my phone battery all of the time!), have a tab to change the pie chart to a bar graph (or just add it below) I love the pie chart, but something about a bar graph with each of my sections listed and colored is just nice), finally I‚Äôd love to be able to add goals (like I want to spend X time on this each week) and then the traveller could mark it off on their journal when completed during the end of focus session log

Overall super happy with this app and can‚Äôt wait to see where it goes! Happy Travelling!

title: Blank Spaces Launcher (-)
content:
This app is everything I‚Äôve been looking for and it‚Äôs working great! Anything that makes my phone less distracting is ideal. The shortcuts work well and it looks fantastic.

Previously, I had used this app while still keeping all my distracting apps (social media, shopping, etc) downloaded on my phone and just out-of-sight in my App Library. That worked well for a bit to reduce distractions, but the app alone wasn‚Äôt enough to reduce how addicting my phone can be. Since realizing that, I‚Äôve deleted all shopping, entertainment, and non-work related social media apps from phone. I‚Äôve turned on the ‚Äúreduce motion‚Äù, ‚Äúgreyscale‚Äù, and ‚Äúreduced white point‚Äù settings on my phone and it‚Äôs made a massive difference! I just ordered a matte tempered glass screen protector to help with the overall glare/intensity of the phone screen. I hope that‚Äôll be the final piece to my ‚Äúsetup‚Äù! 

This app has been incredibly helpful in turning my phone back into a device that works as a tool, not an entertainment device. I can‚Äôt recommend it enough.

title: Blank Spaces Launcher (-)
content:
I love how stylish this widget makes my phone look, but it's too finicky for me to use regularly. 

The app lets you create typographical lists of app shortcuts on your home screen. However, adding apps is a hassle because the search results often show irrelevant apps or give "No results found" if you scroll too fast. 

Another drawback is that once you create a widget, you can't edit it; you have to start over if you want to make changes. Additionally, some apps aren‚Äôt currently supported so the workaround is for the Blank Spaces app to create a shortcut in your shortcuts library. But this shortcut is their to launch another shortcut already in your library. So when you finally have it setup and tap one of these shortcuts on your home screen, you‚Äôre taken to your Shortcuts library where it launches that actual shortcut.  

These issues may be shortcomings of iOS itself. I don‚Äôt know.

Despite its aesthetic appeal, these usability issues make it challenging to stick with this app.

author: Alijah steele

title: ClearSpace: Reduce Screen Time
content:
Ive had clearspace a long time, and the change was not immediate. I have a 189 day streak right now and i only noticed a change like two weeks ago. Before clearspace i was spending up to 10 hours a day on my phone and up to 30-35 hours a week on instagram alone. Now, I spend 5 or less on instagram per week and 40 or less minutes per day. The screen time is the smaller part of why I like this app though; what I really like is the pushup challenge. I used to do cross country but quit a long time ago, and when i started doing the pushup challenge, it was the first time in about two years i saw an improvement in my body and not a steady decline in my physical condition. I did 1 pushup per 3 minutes for a 31 day challenge, and at the end i noticed it was much easier to do pushups, so I started a 100 day challenge with 1 pushup per 1 minute. I‚Äôm a week and a half in and I suddenly realized that over the last month my body has gotten visibly more strong, especially my chest. I can also see my abs more clearly. This little improvement and the fact that I was doing around 50 pushups to 70 pushups a day inspired me, and I finally started working out for the sake of working out again. I lift weights, do pushups, and do core sometimes. It‚Äôs not something I spend a huge amount of time on, but im seeing a gradual improvement in my physical condition and willingness to improve my habits. I highly recommend downloading this app.

P.S.
There are a few things wrong with the app; i wish i could put limits on more than one app for free, i uninstalled youtube to keep myself off shorts as an alternative to reels; however, this isnt a huge problem cause there isnt much to do on my phone anyway. 
I also notice that the app has a very hard time realizing if im doing pushups unless im looking straight at the camera and going slow; this hasnt bothered me too much, but sometimes I‚Äôll do like twenty pushups for ten minutes. Usually it works a lil better when im in short sleeves or when i turn on a bunch of lights.
That‚Äôs all! Amazing app.

title: ClearSpace: Reduce Screen Time
content:
I really like Clearspace and the features offered in the Pro version, and I appreciate the effort behind the app. However, the inability to apply restrictions to an entire category of apps (like all games) at once is a significant drawback. Having to select and restrict each app individually creates a lot of friction and takes much more time than it should.
This tedious process is actually enough to dissuade me from continuing to use the app, despite its other benefits. Managing multiple apps one by one feels outdated and inefficient, especially when many other apps offer bulk management features.
I understand there may be technical limitations due to Apple‚Äôs ScreenTime API, but I strongly urge the Clearspace team to explore solutions for bulk category restrictions or at least a more streamlined multi-app selection process. This improvement would make a huge difference in usability and user retention.
Thanks for listening‚ÄîI hope to see this feature in future updates!

title: Eyezy - Pro Parental Control
content:
I appreciate the built-in GPS tracker that allows me to effortlessly keep track of my kids' whereabouts. It's reassuring to have a quick glance and know exactly where they are. The feature that stands out to me is the ability to establish restricted zones. The moment they enter one, I receive instant alerts, which helps me stay proactive in ensuring their safety. The notifications I receive play a crucial role in staying connected with my loved ones.

Onboarding a child onto the platform is a breeze ‚Äì a simple text with a quick link does the job. Another convenience is the option to log in through Google or Apple credentials. Should any inquiries arise, accessing support is hassle-free; a prompt email can be sent directly through the app.

From the moment I downloaded the app, I was impressed by its user-friendly interface, making it incredibly easy to navigate and set up. Adding family members is a breeze.

One of the most remarkable features of Eyezy‚Äôs its ability to go beyond mere tracking. With its extensive range of useful features, such as the messenger feature, this app has truly thought of everything.

Organizing social gatherings has never been easier, thanks to the convenient check-in feature that gives a visualization of everyone's location on an interactive map.

Moreover, Eyezy boasts a commendable attention to detail,by its constant updates and improvements. The developers genuinely seem invested in enhancing the user experience, making sure the app is bug-free and consistently performing at its best.

In summary, Eyezy is a must-have app for any individual or family seeking a smart and reliable means of staying connected and ensuring their loved ones' safety. It goes above and beyond my expectations.

author: Bakerella79

title: Workout Tracker Gentler Streak
content:
Been using for a few days and already love it! I would give a 4.5 if I could. The one feature I'd most like to see added is a "chronic illness" mode. I got the premium version as an alternative to the much pricier Visible Health subscription. I do love that Gentler Streak tells me when I'm pushing too hard, but it'd be awesome to have an option for saying I have a chronic illness that requires more days of rest that most people / a lower exertion threshold, a place to add in medications and conditions that impact HR, conditions that impact sleep and fatighe, etc.
Otherwise a great app! If you don't have an energy-limiting illness it's an excellent way to move more without the guilt.
author: paradise 57

title: Workout Tracker Gentler Streak
content:
I really love this app and the concept; however, get frustrated by the integration of the HR zones with my other apps. The bulk of my workouts are done at Orange Theory where I wear a heart rate monitor that tracks my HR the entire workout. Unfortunately, this HR data does not fully transfer to the Gentler Streak app, which eliminates the purpose of this app as an exertion/recovery-based indicator. 

As an example, Gentler Streak typically only collects my HR data for ~30-50% of my Orange Theory workouts.

These challenges could be avoided with a manual input of the % spent in each HR zone (this would be in addition to the perceived exertion).

You‚Äôre doing great! Keep it up!

Other apps use all of the health data that Gentler does but other apps give you a ‚Äúwhere is your recovery‚Äù today and a goal range. It doesn‚Äôt say walk x miles but lets you know to take it easy today or if I‚Äôm near 100% and push hard. Every day I have a long workout or game, Gentler gives me a ‚Äúhold up buddy. Know your limits‚Äù. 

I guess this is ok for most people (based on reviews) but I want a little more than a pat on the back and a ‚Äúkeep it up!‚Äù

Interface is nice for what it is. Cheers

title: Workout Tracker Gentler Streak
content:
This app isn‚Äôt just any fitness app, it helps you take care of yourself and keep your body and well-being healthy. When you are not active enough, it encourages you to take action, without the fear and pressure of breaking your streak, and when you overreach, Gentler Streak helps guide you back, and actually encourages you to rest and recover, rather than prompts like: ‚ÄúKeep going! Beat your record!‚Äù To the developers, from the bottom of my heart, thank you for helping me realize my limits, while still helping me achieve my goals! My best wishes to you all! ‚ò∫Ô∏è 
-Nolan

P.S: Gentler streak is great with any smartwatch, but the Apple Watch is the way to go! Thank you for thinking of those of us that don‚Äôt have an Apple Watch! ‚åöÔ∏è
author: Nolan 13!

title: Workout Tracker Gentler Streak
content:
The "Gentler Streak" fitness app encourages a self-compassionate approach to exercise and provides a balance between fitness and rest. It offers personalized suggestions for daily workout actions, which can range from rest to intense workouts. It helps me - a 67 year old guy who values a balanced approach to fitness and well-being - stay within healthy activity levels. 

With an intuitive UI, it‚Äôs so easy to use, even my grandma could do it‚Äîand she can‚Äôt tell a smartwatch from her headstone. It‚Äôs easy to understand and won‚Äôt leave you sweating the small stuff.

The app‚Äôs feedback is so encouraging, it‚Äôs like having a cheerleader in your pocket. It‚Äôll lift your spirits higher than a kettlebell! 
Additionally, the app provides relevant, actionable insights and expert knowledge in short reads. 

It earns 5 üëçüèºüëçüèºüëçüèºüëçüèºüëçüèº from me!

title: Workout Tracker Gentler Streak
content:
I don‚Äôt know what the intent behind this app is, because all it seems to say is that I‚Äôm overreaching. I took two short (10 min ea) bike rides and it said I was overreaching for a day before telling me to exercise. Then I took one long bike ride (2 hrs) a week ago and today it still says I‚Äôm overreaching and need to rest. I haven‚Äôt even taken walks since then! If you want to build your fitness level go find an app that will actually push you. If you want to feel good about being lazy download this app. 

 Edit: I just got a message that I need to log a workout (even though I just did one yesterday) and it STILL says I‚Äôm overreaching.

Edit 2: I didn‚Äôt open it for a couple weeks and the widget said for all of that time that I was either well rested or overreaching. It never said I was on the right track and it took days to go from overreaching to the well rested, never stopping in the middle. Then today I got a mea culpa message when I opened the app saying their onboarding was messed up and they were going to fix that. Near as I can tell nothing has been fixed. Go find another app, this one is not good.

title: (Not Boring) Habits
content:
Habits is one of the best habit trackers I‚Äôve ever used. It‚Äôs beautiful, fun, encouraging, and the satisfaction of getting another level makes it so I don‚Äôt need 50 notifications a day to open it (and it doesn‚Äôt send you a ton like other apps.)

The big problem is it‚Äôs subscription. It‚Äôs $70/year if you want any decent ‚Äúskins‚Äù, the cheaper tier doesn‚Äôt include any fun ones. That‚Äôs way too much for a habits app.

Theoretically it includes 3 other apps, but this is the only good one. The other apps included are extremely over-designed and underpowered, an example of when you have designers over following trends who‚Äôve never used the app they‚Äôre building. The calculator app is great until it lags while you type a 3 digit number, the weather app doesn‚Äôt look as good or act as well as the stock weather app that‚Äôs free or something like Carrot weather which is cheaper. The timer app has no live activity support, doesn‚Äôt support hours, and is just all around unusable. Out of all the apps, this one feels like the devs never opened a timer before in their life.

Anyway, great habits app, shouldn‚Äôt cost as much.

author: taxfraudthegreendino

title: Ochi: Block Websites & Apps
content:
I have been looking for a blocker for both apps and websites while I am at work. After quite some research, I settled on Ochi, which is really easy to set up and works on both macOS and iOS. Ochi has all the modern perks of a native Apple app, supporting Shortcuts and iCloud syncing among other things. The developer is very responsive to support questions. The free version is beyond generous, offering a single filter that can be configured to block an unlimited number of apps and websites together. 

The only major limitation on macOS so far is that website blocking does not work on Firefox (for which I use LeechBlock, an open-source extension). Web blocking works very well on Safari and Chrome-based browsers. On iOS there are more system limitations, but Ochi has managed to accomplish a lot within these limits. It is particularly clever to use the Focus mode for macOS control of Ochi filters across Apple devices.

title: Ochi: Block Websites & Apps
content: As a longtime Freedom user I've been dissapointed with that app's lack of new features, especially the lack of support for Shortcuts, so I was really intrigued when I read about this app on 9to5Mac. Unfortunately, it just reallly doesn't feel ready for primetime yet. In my experience so far on an M1 Mac, the app has been pretty much unusable, with lots of beach wheels and complete unresponsiveness. Even worse, when I tried to set up a filter with specific apps blocked, it ended up blocking apps I had NOT selected, ones that were CRUCIAL to my workflow. It was a huge waste of time and really frustrating. I had to force quit it with the activity monitor, and I'll be putting it away for now until these bugs get addressed.

I loved this app at launch, so it‚Äôs a bummer to see that development has slowed down considerably (especially since the app uses a subscription model). Lately on iOS I‚Äôve been able to bypass the filter by simply clicking ‚Äúreopen site‚Äù, which normally would refresh the page but still ultimately lock me out of the site. Maybe this is a new issue to iOS 16. Given the feature set overlap with Focused Work, which seems to be updated more frequently than Ochi, I‚Äôve got to wonder if this app shouldn‚Äôt just be folded into Focused Work.

author: mykinosu

title: Parental Controls by Ohana
content:
I am 15 and my mom used this app for me instead of the built in screen time. It was personally embarrassing for any of my peers to see that not only did I have screen time as a high schooler but I had an app called Ohana. The app made it so my mom could see everything on my phone, and would look at everything on it which made me feel like I had no privacy in anything. Because not only could she track me but she could control and see everything on it. She would constantly question me on websites I was on which led to many misunderstandings and fights that could have been avoided. This also made me feel like I had no control over anything which crushed my self esteem, and would make me feel constantly angry with her and her need to control my life. It‚Äôs stupid to center your life around a phone, but to my generation we need a little freedom and a phone is a big step of freedom and having that taken away feels terrible.
So not only did this app lead to many fights that could have been avoided it made me have a sense of no freedom and caused me to get made fun of by my friends. If you get this app please don‚Äôt use it as my parents have.

author: JessikaJessikaJessika

title: ADHD Lifehacks For Adults Pro
content:
Unlike Neurotypical folks, I need to see/read/hear something MANY times before it becomes a ‚Äò Go To‚Äô or becomes an Action to develop a Habit around. I ‚ÄòBELIEVE‚Äô that by saving info in an ADHD File I my Cloud, Printing out a copy & pining it to my ‚ÄúLüëÄK Center‚Äù or even flagging a page in a book will cause me to ‚ÄúRe‚Ä¢Visit‚Äù these GREAT IDEAS when I‚Äôm ready to write them in my Habit Tracker section of my BuJo‚Ä¶. WRONG‚Ä¶..

THIS APP is the ONLY WAY THAT WORKS! It is almost Gamified in that it ‚ÄòPops Up‚Äô each day all fresh & new! However, I‚Äôve now developed a routine with a digital list & the ‚ÄúLatest‚Äù hack as an entry‚Ä¶. I then review this list at the end of the month and add on to my Habit-Tracker for the next month.

THIS APP HAS CHANGED MY LIFE! More than ADDitude Website/Magazine App or any other Specialized App for Neurodivergent folks like me!

I‚Äôd also like to add that I‚Äôm 57 years old‚Ä¶. You CAN teach an old dog NEW TRICKS!!!  

THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR THIS APP!!!!

Like some other reviewers stated, the alarm that sounds when the time has ended for a step needs to be louder. Another suggestion is that an alarm sounds when there is a minute left for completion of the step rather than 30 seconds. 

As I have been using the app for about a month and have paid for the yearly subscription, I intend to keep using it. Hopefully my suggestions, as well as those communicated by others, will be given serious consideration and the app improved in turn.

title: BePresent: Screen Time Control
content:
Yesterday it tracked over 50 hours of screen time and I downloaded the app in the afternoon. It‚Äôs my first morning at 8:45 AM and I already have 21 hours of screen time. The only app I was running was Hulu cuz I run shows while I sleep, and the settings show the tracking should be turned off for that app. It says I was in my banking app (which is not and was not open) for 7.5 hours and that I played a game for three hours that I only played for about fifteen minutes before I fell asleep last night. 

I like the app but it‚Äôs kind of a lot of money for it to be this insanely inaccurate. The help article about it says it‚Äôs Apple‚Äôs fault lol.

On top of this there‚Äôs no way to exclude single apps from screen time, just categories of apps. This isn‚Äôt a problem though because the tracking is so ridiculously bad that it doesn‚Äôt matter if it‚Äôs tracking the time or not.

The blocking features are pretty good though and it might be worth paying for it just for that, but it‚Äôs a YEAR subscription, no way to pay monthly‚Ä¶ right now with the tracking so bad I‚Äôm having concerns committing to a whole year‚Ä¶

title: BePresent: Screen Time Control
content: I have a very strong mindfulness meditation practice, but I still find myself occasionally scrolling for too long on Instagram and using my phone as a distraction. This app seemed like a wonderful idea and I love the name and concept, so I thought I'd give it a try. Like some others have stated, it offers you a free trial followed by a year long subscription, and if you don't accept that it will offer you 60% off. The catch is if you take the discount, you don't get a free trial and they charge you right away. And I very quickly realized that the app doesn't work for me. It has too many features and things I don't need and I actually find it a little bit overwhelming and excessive. That said, I do think it could be helpful for a lot of people. I find that downtime is a suitable option for me and basically just a simplified version of what this app is. But if you like having a streak and a bunch of different options to connect with people, track progress, receive gifts and reminders, and if phrases like "please I'm begging you open instagram" deters you from opening it, you might love this app. I'd personally rather work on my mindfulness practice and addiction to distraction as a whole which also helps lower screen time. Apple denied my two requests for a refund, they deny 95% of my requests which is very frustrating because they are all authentic and valid requests, but I reached out to the company and they were very friendly and did offer me a one time refund after I explained what happened. And I appreciate that they responded and offered this refund which most companies don't. I don't think it's a scam, but I did tell them that I felt like I was sort of tricked into buying a subscription and for an app that is meant to improve your well-being, to push so hard for someone to make a purchase just doesn't feel very aligned with their purpose. However, I do understand that everyone needs to make a living and if this app does help people use their phone less then that is wonderful.

title: Ultimate Focus - Visual Timer
content:
I appreciate the functionality of this timer; however, I have a couple of suggestions:

1. It would be beneficial to incorporate the ability to run multiple timers simultaneously.

2. Presently, when I set a timer for 30 minutes, it occupies half of the displayed circle, while a 60-minute timer fills the entire circle. I recommend adding a feature that allows the circle to represent the full visual space, regardless of the timer duration. For instance, if I set a timer for 15 minutes, it should visually occupy the same amount of space as a 60-minute timer does currently.

Thank you for considering these suggestions!

title: Clarify: ADHD Organizer, Timer
content: I signed up for a 14 day trial for $1. I found the app very overwhelming and canceled after 4 days through the app. I received two emails confirming I had canceled and asking me to try it again. I was then charged $29.99 at the end of the 14 days and immediately contacted the company for assistance in 3 different emails. They just repeatedly sent me a link for directions on how to cancel the subscription in the app, refused a refund and said they were closing my case ignoring the attached photo evidence that I HAD canceled and my comments thst I could not log in to the app to cancel as they were directing because they had canceled my suscription so my login didn‚Äôt work. I had to dispute the charge with Paypal who quickly resolved the case in my favor.
author: Scout Bennet

title: Clarify: ADHD Organizer, Timer
content:
I had really liked Fabulous and its kind reminders. And even though I didn‚Äôt actively use it a lot, I kept the notifications on because they were kind and didn‚Äôt set off my demand avoidance. I had also tried the other apps and found them to be pretty good, even if I didn‚Äôt end up using them.

When I saw one for ADHDers I was really hopeful. So I signed up.

I am super disappointed with the notifications daily that ask me about Dentist (I have anxiety around the dentist) or Date Night (which I have little time or money to afford), that ask me about memory lapses and forgetting things and start with ‚ÄúCrikey‚Äù as if to tell me oh no you messed up again, and remind me about having intense emotions.

None of these notifications help me feel positive about things I need to do. I end up feeling angry and criticized every time I get a reminder of how forgetful I am and unpleasant feeling I have. And of course, being an ADHDer, I forgot to cancel before my free week was up.

I‚Äôm really regretting paying so much for a year of this. I now will have to cancel my Fabulous app, which I did enjoy, because I can only afford one.

I will likely end up deleting this app and will also likely forget about even wanting to use Fabulous after the negative experience with an ADHD app that reminds me daily of things I have been criticized for my whole life.

Not sure how the research supported this one. Huge disappointment üòï
author: ughhhhhhh everything is taken

title: Clarify: ADHD Organizer, Timer
content: They ask all the right questions, and while the AI isn‚Äôt always helpful for niche tasks, it‚Äôs the best focus app I‚Äôve tried. My only gripe is that I wish I could customize the reminder voice and the background ambiance music; certain music is distracting for specific tasks and can trigger the voice. ADHD is a spectrum, and I know that you cannot cater to every individual who uses it. Still, I understand it's not cheap to do that, and I love that you try to keep the app affordable.

author: Jjaezflipper

title: Clarify: ADHD Organizer, Timer
content: This is a predatory app. It advertises to people who have a disorder that makes it difficult for them to remember to cancel a free trial, so they end up paying for a premium prescription they do not want and do not use for several months. I did not find this app to be any more helpful than other free or low cost organizing/productivity/timer apps for ADHD - they are all the same. This app is visually overstimulating with juvenile graphics and a user interface that is not intuitive. This is not supportive to folks who actually have difficulty with focus and attention. And then when you do remember you have this silly, expensive subscription, it is almost impossible to cancel because you have to remember how you signed up (which was likely impulsively), and it took several password recovery attempts through various emails to finally access my account to cancel it. I paid for at least one month extra because of the barriers to cancellation. Anyone with ADHD knows that once there are too many steps, we often give up and say we will get to it later- only for a month to go by before we remember. This was developed by folks who know ADHD well and the vultures have used this knowledge to prey on vulnerable individuals.

author: SlayQueen20713

title: Unpluq: Reduce Screen Time
content:
Get  premium. Get the RFID tag. If you‚Äôre serious about reducing your screen time, this is the app you‚Äôve been looking for.

Just set your anti-distraction schedule, then leave the RFID tag that lets you break that schedule in a hard-to-reach area. I leave my tag at work when I go home and set my blocked apps schedule to engage when I go home. I‚Äôm present with my family and my devices are less tethered to me. It‚Äôs worth the money. You get your life back.
author: Stitch Dicks

title: Unpluq: Reduce Screen Time
content:
I like the idea of this app and even bought the tag to help me further break some bad habits. I‚Äôm continuing to use the app and tag but have noticed several bugs or defects while I‚Äôve used it. On occasions when I have temporarily disabled a couple of my schedules but not all of them, the schedules that I have disabled continue to run, restricting access to my apps. For example, I have a schedule that restricts apps from 8 AM - 5PM, M-F and another that blocks shopping apps 24/7 while I was on an no-spending challenge. I disabled the 8-5/M-F schedule because I was on vacation but wanted to keep the shopping apps blocked and the app continued to block my other apps that were in the 8-5/M-F schedule. I ended up having to also disable my shopping 24/7 schedule to get access to the apps in my 8-5/M-F schedule. 

Today at 7:15 AM, I needed to disable my 8-5/M-F just for today so clicked on the prompt ‚ÄúDisable for Today‚Äù when I was asked and all of the apps listed in that schedule became blocked. First off, I just disabled it and second off, it wasn‚Äôt even 8 AM so even if it wasn‚Äôt disabled they shouldn‚Äôt have been blocked.

These inconsistencies, bugs/defects are annoying and frustrating especially because I have the tag and can‚Äôt just unblock my apps without either scanning it (which is annoying because I but the tag in the garage on a high shelf to add friction) or use emergency mode. I‚Äôd like to eventually shut off emergency mode so I can‚Äôt use that loophole but can‚Äôt do that with the issues that I‚Äôm having.

Again, love the idea and if you don‚Äôt have to make changes to your set schedules then it‚Äôs awesome. I‚Äôve found that I‚Äôm more present and focused at work and during time with my family but those glitches are pretty annoying. Had I not bought the tag, I‚Äôd probably be deleting and trying a different app but I‚Äôm going to stick with this one for a while longer in hopes of improvement.

author: ornand 2.0

title: Unpluq: Reduce Screen Time
content:
This is one of the only blocking apps that allows you to scan a QR code to unlock. I have one stuck to the fridge so that if I want to use a distracting app I have to go physically to the fridge, which works quite well. Unfortunately, it doesn‚Äôt allow you to lock it to a specific QR code, so I can bypass it by scanning any random QR code, eg I can scan any pass/ticket in Wallet on my watch. Since I wear my watch to bed this somewhat negates the barrier to midnight doomscrolling of having to trek downstairs to the kitchen. I‚Äôm mostly successful with pretending I didn‚Äôt discover that, but it does require a bit more willpower.

(To the devs: the alarm clock app Alarmy allows you to lock it to a specific QR code, if you want inspiration! It seems to work by just storing the text it read from the code. This allows me to generate different codes and specify for example that I have to go to my exercise bike to shut the alarm up some mornings, and just the kitchen other mornings. Similarly it might be useful to be able to block some apps with a QR code I put on a keyring and other apps with a QR code that stays at home for example.)

I figure it‚Äôs possibly intentional if they‚Äôre trying to funnel me towards buying the actual unpluq device, but I‚Äôm happy enough paying monthly, I shouldn‚Äôt have to also buy a fairly pointless object to make the app work better.

If they ever implement specific QR codes I‚Äôll increase to 5 stars.

Finally I think this is more of a limitation from iOS than Unpluq, but it would seem you have to use only Safari if you want website blocking to work. Ideally I‚Äôd still be able to use Chrome and only block eg news websites and Reddit.

The app itself is good. The premium offers a limit of 49 apps blocked which is better than 2 in the free version. The app shines with the Tap Tag. It‚Äôs well boxed and protected in transit. It has a good feel to it as well and comes with a connector to connect it to keys or a backpack. Would like to see unlimited app‚Äôs blocking like the android app. Maybe that will be added sometime in the future. The tap tag comes in a nice gift box with a little instruction card insert. title: Unpluq: Reduce Screen Time
content:

I keep the tag in a jar on a shelf, and having ti walk over and get it prevents probably 99% of my idle scrolling. It‚Äôs been a huge time saver and also helps me feel less distracted in general. I had tried apps that set timers but they weren‚Äôt flexible enough, so had been looking for a solution exactly like this. It really works!

And Caroline, the CEO, has been wonderfully responsive to questions‚Äîthe customer service is excellent. Five stars!

title: BetterSleep: Relax and Sleep
content: I‚Äôve had this BetterSleep App since before it was called BetterSleep, used to be RelaxMelodies. My mom and I both used it for the last decade or so and I still use it every night. I‚Äôve tried Calm and other sleep apps, meditation apps, even adhd ones, or lucid dreaming specific apps. None of them hold a candle to BetterSleep‚Äôs consistently nor quality. I used the free version for most of the last decade, but switched to the paid version when they added a ton more meditations a couple years back. $29.99 per year is a steal for this app. I recommend the free version too. Whichever works with your budget is worth it. The paid version unlocks more sound choices and meditation choices, but the free version served my family well for many years as well. HIGHLY RECOMMEND over anything else on the market in the sleep or meditation app realm. I will NEVER get rid of this app or stop supporting it. Real customer, not paid/compensated for this review.

author: evonne

title: BetterSleep: Relax and Sleep
content:
BetterSleep was my primary sleep app from 2014 to 2025: unfortunately, the app has changed to try to capitalize on other sleep app markets in ways that have made the app hard to use.

As a soundscape app, the ratio of free-to-upcharged noise options has drifted with updates over the years. The most recent app update reduced access to sounds to the single digits: insult to injury, mixes that are user made and have been in use for years are still stored but inaccessible. Someone new to the app wouldn't be able to build mixes they like and get to know the value of the sound library, and the change leaves a sour taste for a long time free user familiar with the library.

There's been a rapid pivot to serve as a sleep hygiene management app, but it unfortunately also doesn't have features that are competitive. BetterSleep does not offer wide ranging integration with sleep tracker devices, which would be the biggest draw that could tip the scales towards investing in a membership on top of my fitness tracker app's membership.

I'd really love to see BetterSleep refind its footing as a competitive free soundscape app and (sleep tracker-friendly!) sleep management features for an additional cost.

title: Time Timer
content:
I don‚Äôt usually leave reviews but I‚Äôve been struggling with ADHD and completing simple things at work. I‚Äôve been watching videos, and many people have suggested using a visual timer. I was really excited to see there was an app that looked similar to the physical timer. I have this set up on my desk using my iPad. This works most of the time but frustrates me more than it should.

The Good:
- I love that there is a visual timer and it‚Äôs fairly easy to set

The Bad:
- When the timer is minimized or I switch apps, the sound, nor the vibrations go off
- this app does not support split screen on the iPad
- When I have my iPad set up (horizontally) on my desk, I cannot select a new timer in full screen. I have to get out of full screen and then select a timer.
- A lot of times, when positioned horizontally, it will not allow the timer to go into full screen

Overall, it is not bad, but it could definitely use some work

title: AT&T Secure Family¬Æ parent app
content:
The old app did what it was supposed to do, for the most part. The new app is a pain to set up. I use it to keep track of an elderly parent in another state, I don‚Äôt have access to her phone and there is no way I‚Äôm going to be able to explain it to her over the phone. I was not given an option to opt out of this ‚Äúupdate‚Äùthe old app suddenly stopped working and I was forced to download the new one. Doing so necessitates setting up the app all over again on five phones. I have checked the settings with tech support but I still can‚Äôt see my kids much most of the time. Frustrated that I‚Äôm paying for an app that used to work but now does not.. I‚Äôm in the process of looking at other options but I‚Äôm finding that most of these tracking apps have serious security issues so keep that in mind when looking for alternatives.
Update‚Ä¶. Spent 6 hour‚Äôs over the last 4 days trying to get the app to work correctly. New app will not send any kind of invite text or email. Tech support had us delete and reinstall the app and now I can‚Äôt get on the app because I‚Äôm not the primary number and no invite gets sent or received.no one at tech support can tell me why. Cancelled our subscription.

author: Daily Critique

title: Relax Meditation: Guided Mind
content: So I got this app around maybe two(ish) years ago and loved it. I suffered from extreme anxiety, agoraphobia and had panic attacks almost every other day. Life was pretty excruciating. After trying the sample meditations I started to notice that my attacks were coming a bit less often. I went ahead and bought the full app (that‚Äôs right, bought, not rented, not subscribed, bought, for a one time price) as well as talked my wife into trying one of their sleep/clock apps. Everything was great. Over time after meditating around the same time every day, my anxiety almost disappeared. I eventually did most of the meditations multiple times and with my anxiety not quite gone but better than it had been in years, I sat it down for a while while I waited for some new meditations. I‚Äôm not gonna lie, I didn‚Äôt use the app for a long time after that, maybe 6 months or more but it never left my home screen, I never uninstalled it or anything. Eventually my anxiety started bothering me again back around Christmas so I pulled out my handy dandy anxiety busting meditation app only to find that the app that I BOUGHT for just a couple of dollars had been taken back from me and that I could now rent it BACK from them for a ridiculous amount of money a month. My progress is all still there, I‚Äôm just locked out of it. I understand the devs have a right to make money and to charge whatever they see fit. I just don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs right to sell someone something only to take it back away from them and try to rent it back out to them again for thousands of more dollars. If it was to be changed I feel like the changes (a monthly subscription fee) should have only applied to people who downloaded/installed the app AFTER the decision to change it from a flat price to a subscription fee had been made and not forced upon those who had already paid for the full version. I was originally gonna leave a review around Christmas when I discovered what had happened but was just blown away and I guess hurt. I didn‚Äôt want to talk or even think of it. Smh

author: Lifeolemons

title: Breathing Zone
content:
I‚Äôve been using this app for a week after comparing and test driving a few others.  I really appreciate the way you can start at a number of breaths and then the app progressively adjusts to the desired number of breaths.  

However, it could be better.  While I like how you  can set your target number of breaths, the app is missing the ability to control how long it takes for you to get to that desired number of breaths.  For example, if you‚Äôre doing a 20 minute session it would be nice to be able to set to have it slow down over the first 5 minutes... or 10... or whatever your preference is.  As it is, I know it goes slower but I have no idea how long it takes, nor is it possible to see how many breaths you‚Äôre doing at any particular time, which beings me to...

While the session screen is moderately cool with the pulsing orb thing, it‚Äôs kind of useless.  More helpful would be an option for an easy to see (always on while using the app) display of how much time is left in your current session as well as the current breaths per minute.  I‚Äôd like to be able to glance briefly at the screen and see how I‚Äôm doing and if I‚Äôm at my desired breath rate.  

Another minor complaint is that the app pauses very easily - by just touching the screen - which I‚Äôve unintentionally done many times while in a session.  A more deliberately styled pause button would be better.  

Not a bad app but these adjustments would make the app perfect for me and one that I would use much more personally and be able to recommend much more highly to others.

author: tofu-RS

title: Timer+ Timers and Stopwatches
content:
Hi, Pro subscriber here. I sent a message on August 23rd through the app about an issue I'm having but I still haven't received a response as of yet, so I'm following up with this review.

After recently updating my phone to iOS 18.6, the Timer+ app hasn't been working properly. The issue involves the widget or live update not showing the remaining time on the Lock Screen.

I have a 20-minute countdown timer that I use for time blocking purposes, which works fine if I don't add or subtract time from the 20-minute default. However, once I add time, the Lock Screen shows the initial time that the countdown started with, frozen at that time. This also happens with the quick timer feature.

I want to be able to lock my screen and not have the app open in order to see the remaining time, as it helps save battery. Otherwise, I can't really use the app since it requires too many steps to check the time, which would be disappointing. This has been my go-to productivity app for the past 3 years.

What's the point of paying for a Pro subscription if there's no support to help with issues? I'm frustrated that despite reaching out nearly two weeks ago, I haven't heard anything back.

*UPDATED REVIEW 9-6-2025*

As soon as I posted this review the App Store refreshed and allow me to update the app which is now better than ever. This app is 5 stars ‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

title: Priority Matrix
content:
I used this app a few years ago and, as life changes, it sat unused for a time.  I went back to use it and found the pricing strategy had changed - but a call to support was super helpful...

I‚Äòm using it now on Windows and iOS ‚Äî a couple weeks in and it has me so much more effective with my time!!  (And I‚Äòve used and use a variety of productivity apps from simple lists to true organizers)

This one provides a visual that I need ‚Äî and things no longer get lost. 

‚Äî‚Äî Love, Love, Love that i can focus in on a single project with the 4-square visual of all the details. 

‚Äî‚Äî     And LOVE that i can switch to the ‚ÄúMaster List‚Äù or ‚ÄúCalendar‚Äù view to know exactly what i should be focusing on at any given point in time. 

Other good (and key) features is the ability to customize the quadrant for different projects ‚Äî my ‚Äúlearning/development‚Äù goals are captured one way, my home and work ‚Äúprojects‚Äù have a more typical 4-square matrix. 

I use this for myself although it‚Äôs actually created for team use - i would imagine it‚Äôs a great collaboration tool... 

Love it!!!

author: zoozol56

title: Microsoft OneNote
content: Useful because I can use the hierarchy to effectively store many different subjects, notes, plans and lists and access them from my PCs and apple phone, which I do multiple times a day. Frustrating for several bugs that have existed for a decade that get in the way of working.  1. Synching works well most of the time when all devices are in the home LAN but not so good at times or when not at home.  I can write some at home for an appointment on PC, then get to the appointment and it‚Äôs not there. No amount of Synch Now will synch it. ( and why are the synch commands different per platform?) 2. Often when I open the app on my phone it is immediately in drawing mode so that my first attempt to scroll results in a line instead of a scroll. I have to hit the undo key to erase the line and then hit the done button to get out of drawing mode. 3. Sometimes when I open the app on my phone or iPad, the text is corrupted with either lines missing , cut in half or with long bars where characters ought to be that looks sort of like barcodes in part of the document. To remedy I have to go to a different sheet or document and come back for it to render. 4. When I re-order a sheet within a page it gets in a weird mode where instead of allowing me to immediately select another sheet, it starts multi selecting sheets.

It appears that with the new Trello forthcoming, card mirroring (across boards) will be available with the Standard $5/month version. Also, when adding something from a website, the list of workplaces is no longer in alphabetical order and is completely random, so you have to scroll through all the workplaces to find the right one. title: Strong Workout Tracker Gym Log
content: I‚Äôve been using this app for 5 or 6 years and have really enjoyed it. The recent update, however, has removed some of the most useful features. Can‚Äôt do that anymore. When adding an exercise to a template, the app will use the same weights & reps as the last time you performed that exercise, which is handy. If I modified a weight or rep count, it used to roll that change down to all the subsequent sets. It no longer does that - I have to update every single set by hand. It‚Äôs a pain when coach programs 10x3 with +10 lbs from the last week. Those 2 changes have made the app significantly less useful to me. It‚Äôs still nice to have all my history in one app though.

title: Asana: Work Management
content:
NOTE: This is NOT a review of Asana in general, but it‚Äôs strictly a review of the latest version of the iOS app. I mainly use Asana on the desktop and I give it 10 stars out of 5! It‚Äôs the only productivity app that I have kept and continue to use.

I‚Äôm not sure what they did to this app, but the latest version is horrible. It starts up in half-screen mode and you can‚Äôt maximize it. I usually view projects in board view and loved the fact that previously you could just click on the ‚Äú+‚Äù sign in each column to add a new task. But I guess that was too efficient because the ‚Äú+‚Äù sign is gone. Now you have to click on the big ‚Äú+‚Äù at the bottom left and jump through ten hoops to create a task. WHY? Please fix this mess.
author: TwinMoons

title: Asana: Work Management
content:
I am shocked that this app has a 4.7 average rating. 
My entire days are structured around asana tasks, and I have the app open on my computer and phone for most of the day. The desktop version is amazing ‚Äî no other task management software has the same capabilities or UX. However, the iOS app is seriously lacking:
1. ‚ÄúMy tasks‚Äù view will not update task due dates or names unless you force quit the app. This means I have to force quit and reopen the app every time I check my tasks, in case due dates have changed
2. No offline mode
3. No weekly calendar view for tasks ‚Äî only daily or monthly

I would give one star due to the first item listed above, but rated two stars because the app has a widget which is actually fantastic for the Home Screen.

author: gracieisthestar

title: Headspace: Meditation & Health
content:
I love this app and have been a subscriber for nearly a decade. I recommend it every chance I get, and typically meditate daily as a part of my mental health routine. From courses to help with specific challenges, to sleep sounds and music; content for adults as well as for kids - this app covers a lot of ground without making meditation feel like a chore.

There are a few other reviews talking about needing new content. Content has been added, but it‚Äôs been in very particular areas. There have been some new courses added for work life balance in recent years, new sleep sounds get added semi-regularly, and they‚Äôve added the Therapy and AI features recently. While these options are great, they don‚Äôt quite align with my needs. My daughter uses the Sesame Street bedtime stories to help her fall asleep, but there haven‚Äôt been any new ones added in ages (nor has there been any unbranded children‚Äôs stories added to cover the gap)

It would also help if there was more content around temper and outbursts/triggers (and the SOS content is really limited here)

It would also be great if there were reminders to do stress and anxiety check-ins when they open - and it would also be great if those check-ins also reported data back to the Apple Health app.

content: I went through so many time tracker app that I made my own because I couldn‚Äôt find one that was perfect. author: ncjfjfjeid

title: ATracker PRO Time Tracker
content:
I don‚Äôt want to sound dramatic but it actually did save my life.

To summarize myself, let me just say that I‚Äôm a nontraditional premedical student, meaning that I started college late and suddenly decided to become a doctor of all things.

I applied during the 2018/19 cycle and had one interview at UC Davis and was rejected. I was 29 yrs old at the time and it was just heart-wrenching to believe that everything that worked towards didn‚Äôt lead to an acceptance. I didn‚Äôt know what to do with my life anymore. It was so stressed and depressed and plus, I had used up so much of my money saved for this entire process that I was near broke.

I needed to inject some urgency and accountability back into my life. That‚Äôs when I decided to actively look for an app that would hold me accountable for the 24hrs in a day.

Long story short, I started to prepare for the MCAT again. With this app, I took the MCAT 2 more times. I did all of this studying while having a high pressure position at a fertility clinic. On February 25th of 2020, I got my score for my 4th MCAT and I got a very competitive score.

What does this mean? Well, now I have a shot at any US medical programs across the country and most importantly, I can take one step closer to reaching my dream of becoming a doctor.

It all started from using this app to measure literally EVERYTHING in my life: sleep, shower/washing up, socializing, study, eating, working, running errands, driving, gym etc... the list goes on. I wish there is a way to upload a pic of my schedule because it‚Äôs humanly impossible to have done what I did WITHOUT this app.

Yes, I accounted for literally every single minute of my life for about 1yr straight. Funny thing is that I‚Äôm certain that I will continue to use this app for the rest of my life.

ATracker, thank you so much for this app. Your app got me here. So many times, I wanted to give up. I lost count on how many times I thought about ending my life as well. I just keep at it and believed in my process. Today, my world looks so different. What time to be alive. 

Thank you.

author: ml7596

title: ATracker PRO Time Tracker
content:
ATracker Pro has enough features that if you log your time diligently and with intelligently chosen categories, you really will have charts and graphs showing you exactly where your time goes. The ability to categorize specific tasks into larger baskets, and then view your time expenditure in categories rather than tasks, is a particularly cool feature. The pie chart of time can show you for today, this week, this month, or a selected range of dates; I find this very handy. You can also see bar graphs of time spent in specific tasks by period of time. 

I‚Äôve been using this for three months now. As a result I have quit social media, quit Netflix and Hulu, subscribed to the New York Times and the New Yorker, almost finished writing a book I had abandoned, and finally established a truly daily exercise routine (just walking for 40 minutes right now but I plan to upgrade to biking when I feel it is time). Knowing specifically how you are wasting your time, minute by minute, makes it no chore to start spending that time better. It‚Äôs a pleasure to choose the ‚ÄúCategories‚Äù feature on my pie chart and see almost none of that pie chart showing ‚ÄúWasted Time.‚Äù

author: ju self

title: ATracker Time Tracker
content:
I LOVE this app!!! I have been a user for over 6 years and it has saved me SO much time!!!

I work in corporate America and each year (sometimes monthly) my supervisor asks me what I am spending my time on and tasks/projects I have completed‚Ä¶ this allows me to give COMPLETE details to them and allows me the opportunity to discuss where I need help, and how much time it has taken me to complete a project!

It allows me to make notes of where my hang ups are and why I made choices!

I could not ask for a better product!!!

I am also so happy to see them come up with a payment model, as in the past it was free (with lesser options) and I ALWAYS have wanted to pay for it as it has given me SO much‚Ä¶ let alone apple watch integration!!! WOW!!!

I NEVER want to see this app go away, and I do share with everyone I work with! They too say the same on how much they are able to report out on time spent to supervisors‚Ä¶ REALLY a stand out product!!!!

THANKS DEVS!!!

Ps. I am not paid for this and yes I am a normal user that happened to stumble on this app‚Ä¶ my review is true!

For quite long time I tried to find an app that would help me to track my time. Everything I saw in the store was even close to satisfaction. I was seriously planning to invest my own time in implementing it myself.

Now that I found ATraker, I am totally satisfied. It had perfectly balanced and complete functionality I need for my goal: to check what kinds of activities consume my precious time and how I can optimize my life.

Thank you very much for your excellent work!

I‚Äôm dropping some stars in hopes this catches your attention to make some improvements to an app that isn‚Äôt suited to deaf and hard of hearing people. Needs to be ADA compliant.

Great timer! We love how it ticks, so there are both visual and auditory cues. The reward image at the end is great for kiddos that need motivation to stay and wait until the end. Our son has Autism and this is a great timer that we constantly use. It has helped him wait out temper tantrums, potty training, and so many other things. We have recommended this app to several other parents and even his therapists use this now as well! Our son actually also loves the commercials at the end of the time so it doesn‚Äôt annoy us. It‚Äôs actually one of his ‚Äúrewards‚Äù and he looks after it :)
One thing we also love is how the ticking sound accelerates as it gets closer to the last one minute mark. It‚Äôs a great free app!

author: MamaNomes

title: Visual Countdown Timer
content: I have a 2 year old (almost 3) and we had issues with transitions. We used to set Alexa timer but he would get upset when that was done. Now we use this and it‚Äôs a world of difference. We set the timer and show him how much time he has and every so often show him how much time he has left during activity. When it gets close to being done I ask if he wants to want it explode. He understands when timer is done he is done with activity (usually playing for a few extra minutes) and is actually happy to go on with his routine. We have not had as much whining after timer is done and when we have it‚Äôs been minimal. I think being able to SEE how much time he has left is great and he is able to understand that much more then being told he has 5 minutes.

author: Best HIIT timer

title: ALO Wellness Club
content:
I really like this alo moves app.  I have been doing Yoga for 6 years and I guess over time I have become a bit particular.  I like my instructors to know what they are doing, and I want my yoga classes to be a relaxing and unwinding end of my day.  The Alo moves Yoga instructors are top notch. 

 But the second piece of what I am looking for in a class is relaxing atmosphere, which is where the music comes in.  The music should help me to relax and unwind.  Most of the music on the app is great, but some classes have music that includes lyrics.  Here is the problem.  When there are lyrics in the song, and the instructor is also speaking‚Ä¶ that means there are two voices at the same time. Maybe it‚Äôs me, but my brain absolutely cannot make sense of two voices speaking/singing simultaneously.  It may sound weird but it gives me some sort of anxiety because my brain can‚Äôt choose what to listen to‚Ä¶which is the opposite of what I want in a yoga class.  I want to relax. 

Please take out songs with lyrics for yoga classes, or give us the ability to choose our style of music.  I will then give a 5 star rating, as I really do like this app.  Thanks!!

title: TickTick:To-Do List & Calendar
content:
I really enjoy using this app ‚Äî it‚Äôs smooth, useful, and well-designed. I do have a few suggestions that I think could make it even better:
	1.	Add More Fun Visuals: It would be awesome to have more playful or creative features, like uploading our own emojis or using fun reactions. It adds personality and engagement!
	2.	Organize Tasks by Categories/Files: I‚Äôd love a way to group tasks by themes or goals ‚Äî like separate folders for work, study, travel, etc., each with different color codes (similar to Apple Calendar). Maybe this exists already, but I didn‚Äôt notice it.
	3.	Include a Habit Tracker + Insights: Adding a basic habit tracker would make the app feel more holistic ‚Äî great for managing both tasks and personal growth. A simple stat dashboard showing completed tasks, overdue ones, and trends over time would be a helpful bonus. It would give users insight into their productivity and behavior.

Overall, this app is great ‚Äî and with these improvements, it could easily become a one-stop productivity hub!

Natural language parsing, card (kanban) view, recurring tasks with any type of recurrence you can think of, tagging, sharing, comments, a calendar task scheduler, Eisenhower Time Matrix, and the list goes on. On top of it all, they really update regularly to make sure this app stays one of the most complete, bug free task apps available. I have been using it a while now and there is still no other app that comes close.

title: BB - Screen Time & App Blocker

author: J45782

title: BB - Screen Time & App Blocker
content:
I almost never write reviews but this app is fantastic. There are plenty of apps that offer similar services, but this one offers the most for free, and the premium option is far more accessible as well as it‚Äôs a one-time purchase of a very reasonable $5. It also offer more privacy since you don‚Äôt make an account, everything is just stored locally on your device. The schemas are pretty straightforward to set up, and are definitely effective (especially with strict mode enabled). It‚Äôs also great that it works on iPads as well, exactly the same as on your phone, which I found was not the case with comparable (much more expensive!) apps.

I have just a couple of suggestions:
1. The ability to pause schemas for a set amount of time, e.g. ‚ÄúPause for 30 minutes‚Äù or ‚ÄúPause for 2 days.‚Äù Things like that. Or also pause until certain times like ‚ÄúPause until 11:00‚Äù etc.
2. I don‚Äôt know how possible this is in terms of maintaining privacy, but it would be useful to have an in-app screen time tracking feature, where you could see how much time you spent in total, but also see apps marked as productive vs unproductive (either automatically marked by BB or manually selected by the user) to see how much productive vs unproductive screen time you had for that day/week, etc. 

I know it‚Äôs just one person building this app on the side, so I completely understand if these recommendations aren‚Äôt possible for such a small operation, or if they‚Äôd require functions the app simply can‚Äôt access due to iOS limitations, but they are just some ideas I had.

Overall, this app is amazing, especially considering its price (or lack thereof), and I highly recommend it to anyone looking to cut back on their screen usage. :)
author: co.var

title: BB - Screen Time & App Blocker
content: Amazing
author: Clippy cat

title: BB - Screen Time & App Blocker
content:
This app is the best value on the market. However there is still room for improvement in what I would consider basic features.
1. Trying a Siri-powered schema using a shortcut I continuously get the question ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs the schema‚Äù and despite naming every schema I have it never enables one and just keeps asking me. 
2. There is no schema that allows someone to block for a time-period (e.g. 30 minutes). I feel like this should be a basic feature.

title: BB - Screen Time & App Blocker

Putting it simply, its effective and straightforward. The ability to have strict block modes with no workaround is great. One time payment to get access to unlimited schemas.

content:
I‚Äôve always struggled with overusing my phone. I‚Äôll often spend 6-10 hours everyday endlessly scrolling my life away until my eyes are strained and my day is wasted.
This app is honestly a lifesaver. I used to use the app blocker built into IOS, but it was far too easy to bypass. Burnout Buddy has saved me hours, even days of my life in the few months I‚Äôve used it. I‚Äôm able to get more done, have less anxiety, and feel better about my habits. Amazing app.

content: This app has helped change my productivity habits in a short amount of time, and I‚Äôm so grateful! I even appreciate the ‚Äústrict mode‚Äù option.
author: LxSaka

title: BB - Screen Time & App Blocker
content: Doesn‚Äôt try to do too much, just allows me to easily schedule blocks on apps and websites. Much more manageable than the ‚Äúdowntime‚Äù functionality included in Apple‚Äôs ScreenTime controls.
author: JJJJJJJ

title: BB - Screen Time & App Blocker
content: Even the free version of this app is great. I love being able to block different apps and create a schedule. You can block websites too.
author: Pramdit

title: BB - Screen Time & App Blocker
content: I downloaded and got the pro version of this app a while ago, and I am impressed by it's powerful capabilities. You can set up more than just a single Downtime with this app. Imagine having lots of Downtimes at different times of the day, each one having a group of apps, like social media and entertainment, blocked during the period that you set. The app can go further with the power of Shortcuts. I mostly use this app to block apps while a focus is turned on, since most of my focus settings have scheduled times anyway. And even though this app doesn't sync to the cloud, I can set the same groups of apps to be blocked when a focus is turned on across multiple devices, so when I turn on a focus, the same groups of apps can be blocked, this works because focus settings can be set up to sync across iCloud. I have a suggestion, it would be nice to lock my settings with a passcode and prevent the app from being deleted. Overall, this is an awesome productivity tool that I will use throughout my day, along with what's already available with the default Screen Time capabilities.
author: DJAllegretto

title: BB - Screen Time & App Blocker
content:
This app is the best for any screen time management. I was finding no apps that were in my price range that had features I needed. This app has triggers that activate when an app is used for a certain amount of time, and triggers for a schedule, but the best part is Shortcuts integration. This allows you to turn on and off blocking for the apps you want basically however you wanted to, like by location or through any Shortcut. I am more than happy to support this app, and I will recommend it to anyone who wants to have some type of customized screen time solution. Especially with the price being the cheapest, it‚Äôs just the best option. It isn‚Äôt the prettiest, but it gets the job done.

There was one thing I wanted to ask the developers for, when I said it wasn‚Äôt the prettiest. The design of the screen that pops up when you open a restricted app doesn‚Äôt look great. There‚Äôs a lot of text that just doesn‚Äôt seem to have a purpose, and the logo being front and center bugs me. The app still works, and I‚Äôd take this app over any other app for screen time management, but please make it look nicer. Maybe remove the logo, or just say it‚Äôs blocked without so much additional text.
author: t.j.271

title: BB - Screen Time & App Blocker
content: It isn‚Äôt too hardcore like other apps but still keeps me in check! Very cool, and props to the one fella who made it lol
author: Just Jack H

title: BB - Screen Time & App Blocker
content:
As a SAHM, I found myself checking my phone for social media much more than I liked. I felt distracted from my son, and I didn‚Äôt want to set a bad example by being on the phone always. Now I‚Äôm much more present, and I‚Äôve even started reading more because I take books with me to fill the void of scrolling. Now I‚Äôm a better mom and I‚Äôm setting a good reading example for my son. I also feel better at the end of the day. 

This app works so perfectly by allowing you to choose the apps you want to block and the time frame in which you want them blocked. You can also choose to create a time limit for apps if you don‚Äôt want to completely limit your access. It‚Äôs exactly what I needed. Simple and perfect.

author: Ralph T (Brooklyn, NY)

title: BB - Screen Time & App Blocker
content:
I‚Äôve tried all the other apps (Opal, OffScreen, ScreenZen, Brick). All the other ones either offer scammy subscriptions, or cannot block based on schedule, or UX wise just are not there.

This app ticks all the boxes. Easily worth the purchase of pro. I‚Äôm usually very hesitant about spending the money but not on an app like this. And if you paid the subscription free for other apps, you‚Äôre going to pay that amount in a month or two anyway.

Initially I was turned off by the app icon but they provide a much better icon when you sign up for premium. They also let you customize the Lock Screen which is a very nice touch. I would prefer the premium icon being an option there.

They don‚Äôt have the feature in Opal where you can just block everything by default and specify what you DON‚ÄôT want blocked. But honestly, you don‚Äôt really need it. Block all the categories, and then unselect the apps you don‚Äôt need. Same thing.

I would definitely suggest changing that default app icon. It just doesn‚Äôt give a good first impression for how good the app is.

The app ‚ÄúBrick‚Äù gives a way to block Safari as well via shortcut automation, along with detailed instructions in the app as to how to do this. This would be a nice future addition.

The iOS app picker is buggy no matter which app you use. Don‚Äôt blame the app dev for that. But once you set things up how you want them, you mostly don‚Äôt have to deal with it.

Great great app. Best in its class. Extremely cheap. Thank you. Don‚Äôt add subscription model please.
author: Quality reviewer

title: BB - Screen Time & App Blocker
content:
I struggled to find a distraction blocker solution for iOS that could also block browser access, but this app does exactly that. My mindless scrolling hours have almost gone away entirely since configuring the app. 

I also like that it‚Äôs escape hatch is just the right amount of cumbersome to activate.

author: pazzo_lb

title: Habit Tracker - HabitKit
content:
The app is an intuitive, visually pleasing way to track your habits. It does a great job of allowing users to customize their habits while not crowding the ui or creating a convoluted user experience. Overall, it is a near-perfect habit tracker with a nice minimalist aesthetic

Also, the developer shows a lot of respect for the users of the app. I wrote to them regarding some functionality that I was hoping they would add and they quickly wrote back to let me know they were working on that. A couple months later they reached out to let me know they were rolling out that feature! In my experience, it is hard to find a developer that is so genuinely responsive to user feedback

Lastly, the app, which does have a premium option, makes the non-premium version actually worthwhile to use and offers the premium version via both subscription and one-time-purchase. Both of those are big pluses in my book!

title: Cape: Screen Time Master
content: Heard about this app from tips on how to hide stuff. My parents are insanely strict and invasive, scouring my phone every night and reading through all my text convos. This app. Is. A. Lifesaver. I would recommend the pro version to anyone who wants peace of mind, (at the time of this review it‚Äôs only like $8 and it‚Äôs a ONE TIME PURCHASE NOT A SUBSCRIPTION.) The pro version has a lot more app space (5 completely hidden vs 50), and can lock with a passcode. However, my favorite feature is the camo ability. If you‚Äôre being forced to open the app in front of others, you can enter in the decoy password instead of the real one and the app becomes a note app. It makes it just look like a password protected note app and you can even change the app icon to look like a notebook. The BEST thing that I use this app for isn‚Äôt even an advertised feature. I call it my panic button. In shortcuts you can make a fake app cover (tutorials on how to do this are online), and mine functions as an app I can press that instantly hides certain app groups. All in all, this app has saved me literally more times than I can count and I would recommend it to any kid with insanely restrictive parents

author: Theel13

title: Roots: Screen Time Control
content: I have a pretty bad phone addiction, and I got Roots to support me by offering the time limits for apps and also blocked off time. I paid for the subscription so I could have monk mode and the most access to Roots‚Äô offerings. I had to stop using app specific time limits because I would find myself locked out of apps that I needed after only being awake for three minutes. It would tell me that I timed out of my four hours of time limit for a work necessary app at 6:03 AM when I hadn‚Äôt even opened that app. the screen would have the accurate time for my screen usage, but the time limit would be locked anyways. And here I am sitting on my lunch, hoping to have 15 minutes of downtime before heading back into my stressful workday to find that my apps are locked once again when I have no active time limit, and no active blocked out time running. I paid around $30 to find my phone bricked more often than not and while it has significantly reduced my phone time, I also want to be able to use my phone when I find it appropriate. I really hope that these issues can be fixed, and I will be seeking some sort of refund or at least some amount of cheat days added to my account because I should not have to use an entire cheat day that I earned by following my goals because I want to be on my phone for 15 minutes and I‚Äôm finding myself locked out. It does not seem fair to the user and I am very dissatisfied with that.

author: lane whaley

title: Grit: Daily Habit Tracker
content:
I‚Äôve been using Grit for a short time, and it has quickly become one of my favorite productivity tools. The app‚Äôs design is sleek, intuitive, and highly customizable, making it easy to track habits and stay on top of my goals. I especially love the ability to set specific goals and track progress over time‚Äîit‚Äôs a game-changer for habit-building.

However, the one area where Grit falls just short of perfection is the lack of support for non-repeatable, one-time tasks. While the app excels at habit tracking, it would be incredibly useful to have the ability to add one-off tasks that don‚Äôt factor into the overall habit metrics. This functionality would consolidate all my to-do items into one app and eliminate the need for other tools like Apple‚Äôs Notes.

This minor shortcoming is the only thing keeping Grit from being a perfect five-star, daily-use application for me. With the addition of non-repeatable tasks, this app would truly be unbeatable.

Despite this, I can‚Äôt recommend Grit enough‚Äîit‚Äôs a fantastic tool for anyone looking to take control of their habits and achieve their goals. Here‚Äôs hoping this already great app continues to get even better!

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ

author: G.Lenin

title: EndeavorOTC¬Æ: Outplay ADHD
content: I wanted to like this but it‚Äôs just not helpful for me. I did the one week free trial.  I tried to play this daily for the past 6 days, I think I got 4 days in, but I just don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs beneficial for me.  While I‚Äôm playing I feel anxious and agitated. I also hold my breath. The pace is so fast, the angle of the phone is not good for my neck or wrists and as I do better it speeds up so I never feel successful. The repetitive sounds may be designed to be a purposeful distraction, but I find them so irritating. There‚Äôs the ‚Äòoh crud‚Äô when you miss your target (but it‚Äôs strange b/c I am hitting the thumb button but it is almost off the screen and  but not quite but still registers as having missed it) and there‚Äôs the loud command not to miss the power zones &  ‚Äúyou‚Äôre slowing down!!!‚Äù After missing only one. At the pace it goes and with multitasking happening of course I‚Äôm going to miss one or two, I don‚Äôt need that startling distracting reminder which will only make me miss more. The game is repetitive and it continuously has me targeting blue creatures‚Äîdon‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs by design because on the rare occasion I‚Äôd need to target a red or a yellow creature I often forgot and went for blue by mistake b/c I was so used to it. There‚Äôs also all these extraneous bells and whistles with the points, purchasing different characters and uniforms and a farm but I don‚Äôt know what any of that is or how it would benefit me from the standpoint of treating adhd. It actually seems more like a gratuitous dopamine fix that I‚Äôm not interested in. The stats that are shared on my progress mean very little to me because they aren‚Äôt explained in detail. Overall I don‚Äôt see this as having any value for me personally and certainly not at 149 dollars a year.
