author: stupinicknamehere

title: EndeavorOTC¬Æ: Outplay ADHD
content:
Don‚Äôt rely on the negative reviews from people who forgot how the App Store works with free trials and automatic subscriptions, or the people complaining that the game isn‚Äôt the most fun. It‚Äôs definitely fun for treatment and I noticed a difference after my very first session. It gets harder as you improve to keep challenging you, the harder the game gets the easier my life gets. One of my biggest struggles with ADHD is executive disfunction and all the extra time it takes me to start and complete tasks due to all my dilly dallying, committing to this treatment plan has cut down that time DRASTICALLY as well as all of the anxiety and depression that used to result from the struggle. Now I just plan something and I do the thing? I feel so efficient and my confidence has significantly improved. Bonus tip: if you meditate or have a brief period of non-sleep deep rest within four hours of a session (or any kind of study session) it helps your brain to really rewire all of those changes in your brain aka it makes your brain a better sponge for everything you are learning.

***UPDATE*** 
After having this app for almost a year I will not be renewing it or recommending it to anyone. Once all of the levels are unlocked there is no further skill development other than the game getting faster and faster in order to further challenge the user. There is not enough variety in the levels, you are just supposed to play them over and over. All of the positive effects I had noticed in the beginning eventually plateaued.

author: E//.

title: EndeavorOTC¬Æ: Outplay ADHD
content:
I‚Äôve only just begun playing, so I can‚Äôt speak to how deeply the game will impact my attention in the long term, but so far I can see how it would improve focus!

Equally importantly, it‚Äôs a fun game in its own right. It would‚Äôve been easy to just apply the attention mechanic onto a very simple set of repeating tracks, but the designers have gone a lot further that that with the engaging interstitials, worlds, and characters. It feels as though it‚Äôll be much easier for me to keep up the habit of playing daily when the story and design are this much more captivating than your average casual racing game.

As someone who would ordinarily feel guilty about spending 25 min/day playing on my phone, I‚Äôm glad that this feels so much for thoughtful and polished than most games of a similar nature, it somehow legitimizes it for me. Personally, for me it would be absolutely perfect if it felt a bit more ‚Äúgrown up‚Äù, but I do like that the current story/design is appropriate for all ages.

title: App Lock
content:
I bought the paid version. In response to a previous review regarding the free version: think about the value of your private information. The price of the pro version is WELL worth the cost of the upgrade.  

Team, this software is fantastic. Congratulations on a great application!

The tweaks: Say you use the facial recognition (FR) feature of iOS to unlock an app you have locked down. FR evaluates your face, matches it, and redirects you to App Lock. 

I am using the app on an iPhone 15 Pro. My text display is set to large. Also I‚Äôll refer to the control that displays the name of the app you were just using as the ‚Äúback‚Äù text. I‚Äôm unaware of the proper name.

Tweak number one: If you have a larger font set, the prompt that tells you to hit the ‚Äúback‚Äù text is too large for the space it occupies. Consider making the prompt legible in such cases. 

Tweak number two: Allow that prompt to go away, either by expiration after a small number of uses or via toggle in settings. Once people catch on about how to use the app, perhaps they don‚Äôt need to be continually shown. 

Tweak number three: If the Dynamic Island is in use, the ‚Äúback‚Äù text disappears. The current effect is now you have a prompt pointing to a control that isn‚Äôt there. Users must resort to swiping up and re-entering the app they attempted to open; it is now unlocked. 

Wishing you all the best!

author: felinechair

title: App Lock
content:
Just tried this out and my first assumption was: all the thief needs to do is to delete the lock app and then they have access to everything that was locked. Nope! Your only option is to remove it from the Home Screen. As long as the app is ‚Äúon‚Äù (locking apps), you cannot delete it. Cool. I like this. 

Now for the downside. In order to use any of the apps that you‚Äôve locked you have to first open up this app, turn off the locks for all your apps, then use your previously locked app(s), then you have to go back to this app to re-enable the lock. There should be a way to open a locked app and then enter a pin or face/Touch ID to access it (much how apps with this built-in operate). This is too cumbersome and too many steps for frequently used apps. I don‚Äôt like this. 

What this is great for is apps that don‚Äôt offer this additional level of protection. Thankfully a lot of apps do (like bank apps) do. This uses Apple‚Äôs screen time functionality to lock you out of the apps you choose which is great, but again.. too many steps. The developer needs to work with Apple to find a way to bypass the lock without having to do the round trip steps. 

I‚Äôm gonna pass until there is something super sensitive that I have to lock out if my phone is stolen. The annual price isn‚Äôt bad‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt raise it!

author: Bravo‚Äôangelito

title: App Lock
content:
This is a very useful app and could even be a money/life saver if someone gets a hold of your cell phone and has an idea of your passwords (or can get them out of you, somehow). After using it for a couple of months now, I will gladly rate it a 4 1/2 as it is, but it has a potentially dangerous flaw and two programming, nuisances, to wit:

- It should offer the option of disguising the app icon AND NAME to something innocuous, both in picture and name. There is another ‚ÄúApp Lock‚Äú offered in the App Store, that allows for this possibility, i.e. changing the app's icon to something like a calculator, for example, but, strangely enough, does not allow the user to change the app's name. Even though the app's icon (and name) can be hidden from view in your cell phone main screen, the app is readily available via a search of your installed apps, where it shows the icon and name (and it even starts with an ‚ÄúA‚Äù so‚Ä¶). I installed this app, and use it constantly, because my son (who is a programmer) recommended it to me, and I thought that I had achieved almost total security from this standpoint. However, a few days ago, talking to an Uber driver, regarding the cases in which people have had their bank accounts cleaned out via the app installed in their cell phones, he mentioned to me that I could install an app that would hide, the icons, the conclusion to this being that, if an Uber driver knows about this type of app, undoubtedly crooks would also be aware of these applications and would search for them in the cell phone and, if they also have you, they can beat the pulp out of you until you tell them the PIN and, once they have it, they can deactivate the ‚ÄúHide‚Äú feature of the app, and then proceeded to get from you the various passwords and PINs needed to transfer money out of your accounts (some of which will even be, no doubt, set up for facial recognition). The app should allow the user to completely disguise it, BOTH THE ICON AND THE NAME, so that it could not be easily found and deactivated, thust increasing security considerably.  Much easier to "explain" that you do not have any financial apps installed "because of the dangers involved...".

Now, for the programming flaws:

- The PIN used to lock/unlock apps is the same used to access the app itself. They should be allowed to be different, i.e. have one ‚Äúmaster pin‚Äú to activate/deactivate the various features in the app and other pin(s) to block/unblock block apps.

- Finally, when when one is selecting apps to be blocked, or hidden, the program has a rather disconcerting tendency to return to the main app categories screen when one has already chosen a category and began to choose individual apps to be blocked or hidden, and you have to start all over again.

It would be fantastic if the developers could fix at least the main problem (i.e. disguising the app itself so that it would not provide any clue as to its true identity and purpose)

title: ChatGPT
content:
I use ChatGPT to organize things I write, to add emojis. There are things I will have it provide data for to roll into things that I‚Äôm writing. 
I also use it to write Meme‚Äôs and create backgrounds. That is a nightmare. When I do, it is horrible! I often have to work on a meme 30 to 40 times. One line cut off. One word not spelled right. Fonts different sizes. This is the same meme. I provide clear directive time after time. 
Chat gpt is also liberal leaning. I catch it providing misinformation on numerous occassions and called it on it. It then will admit I was correct.  

No AI should cause this much headache! I pay for the upgrade. Such a joke!

title: Llama Life ADHD Routine & Task
content:
I have ADHD and, as an entrepreneur who must focus on tasks to get them DONE (as opposed to partially done in a thousand open tabs), Llama Life has been a lifesaver. Every aspect of the app (which I‚Äôve been using on desktop for years) is a delight, from the colors to the icons to the branding‚Ä¶ it even helps me break down my tasks into steps if I get stuck. Something about knowing I only have to do an unpleasant task for 20 minutes and then I can do something else‚Ä¶ while listening to a focus-inducing soundscape‚Ä¶ it makes the impossible possible.

This is SUCH a worthwhile app. There is none other like it‚Ä¶ and believe me, I have tried DOZENS of apps. This one is both practical and delightful. It‚Äôs beautifully executed. I‚Äôm so glad I found it!

Also, who doesn‚Äôt llove llamas?ü¶ô

title: Llama Life ADHD Routine & Task
content:
I had been using the web version of this app for a while. It is fun which makes me want to use it. Different colors, emojis and confetti when you complete a task. But don‚Äôt let the fun interface fool you. This app has a ton of useful features such as chimes to remind you you were working, automatic breaking down of tasks, integration with notion or todoist (which integrates with Evernote), and loads of other things. The team is super responsive to help you if you run into a snag. 
And did o mention the mini celebration when you complete something? Oh, well, it makes using the app fun enough that I actually do it and my productivity is way higher when I am using llama life!!

title: Llama Life ADHD Routine & Task
content:
I love this. I can set up a morning routine and then it counts down each step of events and how long I expect it to take. Seeing a list with an active count down timer really helps me visualize what I need to do and how much time I have to do it, rather than getting sidetracked.

That said, I really wish this app had some other features (because now I have to use other apps in supplement to this one, which sometimes makes it a bit inconvenient). 
‚Äî I wish the in app sound would offer more than just relaxing nature noises but rather a clock/timer tick sound or a water droplet sound that CONTINUES to play even if you exit the app/start playing music. 
‚Äî This is one of the biggest things- the timer should be able to show and continue running in the Lock Screen or at least create an interactive widget feature. If I close out of the app and I play music or something, the notification simply says ‚Äútimer will keep running‚Äù rather than a current count down of your task / and the ability to mark as complete/etc. This is the biggest inconvenience of the app compared to other promodoro or task management apps. 
IF the second feature was available, this would genuinely be an app I could not live without and would be such an immense game changer.
author: MacadamiaNuts

title: Llama Life ADHD Routine & Task
content: So glad the mobile app is here. This app that wants to protect your time, attention and focus for what you want to do when so many other apps want to consume your attention.

title: Llama Life ADHD Routine & Task
content: I couldn‚Äôt believe how long the smallest of things that we all do in the mornings and evenings take.  Well add ADHD to that and you can see how quickly time gets away from you and you‚Äôre constantly late. This app gently helps you to correct that.  Morning changer for me!!

I don‚Äôt use it every day but when my ADHD throws me for a loop the llama is there for the rescue this way doesn‚Äôt turn into a bad week because by day two the llama gets me back on track. Thank you to the team for the todoist implementation - super convenient . The best part, however, is the ‚Äúsurprise me‚Äù color button. üåà It‚Äôs such a silly thing but I just push that button and I smile! Thank you, Llama team, you are awesome!!!!!

author: cindywhitesides

title: Llama Life ADHD Routine & Task
content: I‚Äôve been using Llama Life for several years now and it‚Äôs helped tremendously. I was super happy when the iOS app launched and I use it regularly to help organize my tasks. I love being able to see how long a task list will take (helps with time blindness) and all the fun visual perks help keep it exciting and fun to complete tasks. Devs are very hands-on, responsive, and listen to users when adding and updating features. Cannot recommend this enough!!
author: AkenanM

title: Llama Life ADHD Routine & Task
content: I find Llama life to be so useful and helpful with my day to day productivity. And it‚Äôs so fun! I couldn‚Äôt live without it.
author: Nattyr2222

title: Llama Life ADHD Routine & Task
content:
I am lucky enough to be part of the development. This team is dedicated to the community, the development of the app and always a pleasure to communicate with. 

As far as the app- I use it daily. What makes it different is the time shown for each task and the total time for a group of tasks. For example, if I need to do my morning tasks I know it‚Äôs a total of 1.5hrs, but I know I have to leave the house in 1hr- then I can adjust the list of tasks and move the tool to show the exact time ie. 8:43AM that it would take to complete all the morning tasks.

I love knowing how long it will take to complete a group of tasks and when that group would be complete. I have over 20+ tasks in a given day. Llama Life is the only way I get these things done!

Pro tip: add a prelist of breaks to add into your task list if you have a hard time taking breaks
author: Bhjddjjj

title: Llama Life ADHD Routine & Task
content: As a mid-life ADHD-er, this app has helped me better understand how time blindness shows up, and has helped me be more realistic in planning my days. Missing a critical time stamp feature!!!! To know what time tasks were started and competed!!! Please add simple time stamp and this app will be supremely useful!!!!
author: Sunshine   Rainbows

title: Llama Life ADHD Routine & Task
content:
This is time-boxing for time-boxing-challenged people!! I have tried for years to time box (after other productivity hacks also failed) only to get off track and wind up overwhelmed and discouraged. I actually quit even trying because I knew I would just waste time replanning and re-replanning if the time slipped. And here is the thing Llama Life taught me. Time sometimes does slip. And it‚Äôs not a reflection on me. Sometimes a task just takes longer or an interruption happens. And the day isn‚Äôt a failure. 

Llama Life has just enough flexibility to adapt to the day‚Äôs situation. But not so much that you could go down a rabbit hole playing around in the app instead of moving through the day‚Äôs to-do‚Äôs. 

I am a paper planner person and have been looking for which one to buy for the new year. I‚Äôm so glad I found LL before I purchased my annual planner because I won‚Äôt need a day planner at all, just a simple place for my goals and projects. I trust Llama Life to help me keep my days focused and productive. And even fun!!

I will be passing along this gift of joy to many loved ones.
author: SooBeeW

title: Llama Life ADHD Routine & Task
content:
I love Llama Life! I have been using it for over a year, and I'm super excited that it's on iPS now! 

Still missing a couple useful features from the web app like Todoist sync, but the devs are working on it. And you can still set things up on the web, let it sync to mobile, and then go from there.

If you have ADHD, like the idea of pomodoro, but struggle with the other apps out there, this app is the miracle you have been looking for!

(And it pairs well with the GTD method). This app halts my habitual tendency to overbook myself (always thinking I can squish more into a day than can be done. . . leading to overwhelm). Llama life helps me set guard rails and calms my projects‚Äîand my mind. Plus the UI is intuitive, pretty, well organized, and whimsical. What a delight. Thank you so much! 5 stars!! No, make that 6. :-)
author: TucsonWriter

title: Llama Life ADHD Routine & Task
content:
I‚Äôve been using Llama Life on desktop for about ten months, and it simplifies and gameifies the dreaded daily to-do list. So to now have this handy system on my phone really transforms the entire day for me! I‚Äôm able to manage my tasks as I‚Äôm doing them in different rooms of the house, or even out and about running errands! As an ADHDer, this is especially helpful as I can get detailed so easily and succumb to distractions and side quests!

My favorite part of Llama Life is how they‚Äôve managed to make something like a boring to-do list into something fun! Confetti, chimes, and the colors and themes just make it more appealing. I save my preset lists for routine-setting, check over my reports to see if I stuck to my time estimation, and even use their AI-assisted emoji matching to make those tasks even more fun. 

Can‚Äôt wait to see what‚Äôs next for Llama Life!
author: Isabella_ringaling

title: Llama Life ADHD Routine & Task
content:
For years, there has been a 30/30-shaped hole in my heart, and I have bounced from app to app searching for a worthy replacement. I found the Llama Life website a few weeks ago and was disappointed to see that it was via Internet only, but then I was almost immediately thrilled to read that an iOS app was to release within the month. Talk about perfect timing! 

Words cannot convey how much this app means to me. As an ADHD woman whose sense of time is vestigial at best, finding a app that works with my brain is like birthday and Christmas rolled into one. 30/30 worked for me, and then it just‚Ä¶ went away. üò≠ I mourned that app the way other people might mourn lost family members. There is no telling how much time and money I‚Äôve wasted searching for a replacement, but the search is finally over! HUZZAH. (That‚Äôs what the kids say nowadays, right??)

To the developers of Llama Life, thank you thank you THANK YOU for all of your hard work. All of the features, the colors, emoji, the ability to break tasks down, to save routines, to easily enter times, the end time estimate, the planned vs. actual time, the divider bar‚Ä¶ This app feels like it was designed especially for me. I cannot wait to see where you take it, and I‚Äôll be a subscriber all the way!

title: Atomic: Habit Tracker
content:
I have been using this application for several days and I love it! It has a simple, friendly and practical design. 

You can add the number of habits you want to work on, choose how many times a day you want to do that habit (e.g. meditate twice a day) and put the number of times you have done it during the day; it has statistical tables that help you evaluate your performance and you can even choose if you want to create or break a habit!

It would be great if it had widgets and could be used on multiple devices. This would help to strengthen the routine to not lose habits. Also, it would not be bad to integrate a focus timer.

It is an application with a lot of potential and excellent for those of us who are convinced of creating good habits that help us create the best version of ourselves!

title: Propel: ADHD Games for Adults

Original review below, but just bumped right to 5 full stars. Developer reached out on colorblind options, made numerous changes beyond feedback. While I haven‚Äôt seen all the new changes, I can confirm several games work significantly better, and a toggle now exists without user profile for colorblind users. GREAT JOB DEV! Thank you for the adjustments. 

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

Onboarding literally asks if you are colorblind, and regardless of what you say you are repeatedly shown color based puzzles without any patterns/textures to assist those who cannot see colors. Could be matching games based on colors, or games where words are a color and you are supposed to know if the color matches the word. Just not a great showing to be aware enough this condition exists, to ask about it, and to do nothing within the app itself to support users suffering from it.

Tried to give this a chance because it sounded promising‚Ä¶shoulda known better. First game doesn‚Äôt even give you a chance to read the instructions before it starts all on its own‚Ä¶this was supposed to be an impulse control game‚Ä¶then when I try to back out to restart it tells me the next time I access the game it will increase in difficulty‚Ä¶I HAVE ADHD! Issues with instructions seeming unclear is a a well established part of that? Who are these ‚Äúpsychologists‚Äù making these apps??? Clearly not those who specialize in ADHD! I doubt anyone with any knowledge of ADHD was consulted when making this app. This is incredibly invasive and feels so scam me. The fingerprint commitment is really creepy.
author: Kinkooooooo

title: Propel: ADHD Games for Adults
content:
After downloading and playing this game for ~ 45 minutes, I came across several claims that caused me to question the integrity of the developers. 

1) upon opening the game, one of the first screens claims something to the effect of, ‚Äú#1 downloaded ADHD app/game.‚Äù Given that Propel currently has <600 reviews and the App Store doesn‚Äôt indicate # of downloads, it seems safe to say that statement is misleading. (I understand that such statements have become more normalized, but that doesn‚Äôt make the en any less deceitful.)

2) After answering the demographic and ‚Äúlet‚Äôs create your plan‚Äù questions, I was faced with the option to sign up for a ‚Äú3-day free trial‚Äù followed by a $49.99 annual subscription fee. I clicked ‚Äúsee other plans‚Äù and was surprised to find the annual plan offered for $39.99 ‚Äú(no free trial)‚Äù. Charging subscribers that opt to use the trial $10 more than those that subscribe sans the trial does not equal ‚Äúfree‚Äù; rather, it equals $10/3 days, or $3.33/day.

3) Finally, I played almost every game at least twice.  I‚Äôm apparently quite good compared to all the other users because I scored better than 93-95% players on EVERY game I played‚Ä¶including the game that I quit four times (number sort with the moving tiles). Quitting the game resulted in a ZERO score every time, and I STILL scored higher than 93% AND 94% of other players! According to this game, I‚Äôm decently bright (it is the #1 downloaded ADHD game üòâ) but I can‚Äôt figure out how I could improve my standing -within minutes! - with the lowest possible score.    Assuming that the lowest possible score is ZERO (were negative scores possible, I would have received one based on how many moves I made before quitting), it‚Äôs not statistically possible for someone who scores 0 (the lowest possible score) to have outperformed 93% of users, because no one can score worse than 0. 
This statistical & coding oversight led me to conclude that the ego-boosting performance stats at the end of games are in place only to keep players playing. Presenting users with a sense of achievement is valuable‚Ä¶especially to the developer. 

If the developer is truly interested in helping those with ADHD (or anyone), they need to attend to the studies that indicate that honest, direct feedback is far more beneficial than sugar-coated or insincere. Instead of spitting out false numbers, consider offering tips on how to improve their gameplay. You ask for and benefit from in-app feedback so you can improve your game; extend the same courtesy to your users.

It even tries to force you to "commit" to using the app before even letting you see what it is. author: aaaacccpl

title: ADHD Planner AI Task: Splitti
content: I have owned a phone for 20 years and this is going to be the first time I ever leave a review. I feel compelled to leave this review because I think that this app is a godsend for people like me who have a combination of decision, paralysis, ADHD and generally completely overwhelmed with life and everything that is being thrown at them. I used to be a very productive powerhouse back in the day before a child and all of the daily urgent responsibilities that have now inundated my life.  I am barely able to keep up now and the last two years have been very miserable for me.  I looked into getting a life coach to help me feel motivated and tap into my passion but also to help me stay organized and on track however after being quoted between 6000 and $7000 I realize that that was not a path that I could pursue. I know that I really need personalized help somebody to be interested and ask me what‚Äôs going on and ask follow-up questions and pitch ideas on how to move forward and so I looked at AI assisted task managers and after testing about four different ones I landed on this one.  It is really really amazing and I haven‚Äôt used all of the features yet, but I‚Äôm really impressed. Of course there are some bugs and kinks that need to be ironed out because I think this app is relatively new, but I really believe in their approach and I wanted to leave this review to thank them and make sure that I can contribute to helping the team and the product to continue growing and providing such valuable support.  Thank you!
author: yshmokes

title: ADHD Planner AI Task: Splitti
content: So I always attempt to plan my projects so that I minimise procrastination and become more efficient but I often have trouble foreseeing the individual or smaller hidden tasks that lead up to big projects getting down without getting off track and I didn‚Äôt expect too much from the AI here but it broke everything down into smaller tasks and then broke that down again ! The prioritization matrix is a must have addition as well. I love having detailed clarity on everything a project might take to succeed and it really helps to eliminate unforeseen obstacles. Very underrated so thank you so much for making this Ô£ø app ! ‚ô° ‚ô° ‚ô°

title: Tomato Timer €¨
content: The free version includes everything you need to get started right away and works similar to any Pomodoro timer. The ability to play the ambient sounds together is unique and might be really useful in the paid version since only two are included for free and one is too jarring for me. It would be nice if the premium ambient sounds could be previewed before purchase. If most people using this app are like me, I‚Äôm very sensitive to sound and generally only find one or two acceptable. If I could hear samples of the premium options, I‚Äôd be much more likely to purchase them. Also, since I do have such a sensitivity to sound, the short sound clips in the free version are distracting. Hearing the track stop and restart every few minutes interrupts my focus. Tracks that last as long as the focus session would be great, but 5 minutes at a time at least would really improve my experience.

author: Lucy Sly

title: Atoms - from Atomic Habits
content:
The app has great user experience and I love the way it builds up and vibrates when you complete a goal. This is very rewarding and provides a great feedback loop, genius idea. The worst part about the app is that you get a free trial and THEN IT restricts your use. 

Most other apps will start you off with limited features and allow you to upgrade to more features, not give you features and then limit you to just one unless you upgrade. 

I don‚Äôt mind paying a one time fee, I don‚Äôt mind there being ads, but I bought the book and move it, I don‚Äôt think the app does enough to warrant $60/year! Seems like a bad habit to get into to pay $60 or more a year for a phone app.  Especially if one of your habits you want to form is to spend less time on your phone or be better at budgeting.

content: The app itself looks great and I was really excited when I found it and it was a big deal for me because once you found an app and you‚Äôre on a streak logging in your habits, you don‚Äôt want to switch apps. However, about a week in I got an email saying I have 21 more days of trial and then it‚Äôs either only 1 habit or 6 if I pay. Originally the fact that the app is paid was undisclosed and I think this is based exactly on what I said before: once you get sucked in, you don‚Äôt want to switch so you‚Äôre ‚Äôforced‚Äô to pay. And this is the reason I‚Äôm not gonna pay as it feels unfair
author: D18765

title: Atoms - from Atomic Habits
content:
I gave the app two stars not because I had any problems using it, but because the Pro version is far too expensive for what you get. I had the app for two weeks and had access to the free Pro version trial for the two weeks I used the app.

A) If I want a reminder to practice a habit, I can just set a repeating calendar reminder on my phone (completely free). The app would need to have significant functionality beyond tracking a habit to be worth paying for the Pro version. Maybe I didn't use the app long enough to discover more functions, but it seems as though the only other useful functions the app provides are the ability to select an accountability partner, access to daily tips (see next comment), and a self-evaluation function.

B) All or most of the articles and tips included with the app can be found on Clear's website or in the Atomic Habits book. Yes, the app makes it easier and faster to access the information; however, having the information slightly more accessible is not saving me $120 a year.

I personally think that this app would only be worth paying around $25/year, based on how much my time is worth. Currently, the app seems to be catering to an elitist crowd.
author: nessa ryan

title: Atoms - from Atomic Habits
content:
I was a fan of James Clear‚Äôs Atomic Habits, so I tried the Atoms app ‚Äî but after the trial and first month, I stopped using it. A year later, I was auto-charged for an annual renewal with no reminder and no warning. I reached out to support the same day of the charge, but was told it was my fault for not cancelling and that no refund would be issued.

This feels like a predatory subscription tactic ‚Äî profiting off people who forgot to cancel rather than providing ongoing value. Definitely not what I‚Äôd expect from a brand built on ‚Äúintentional living.‚Äù Disappointed and disputing the charge.

If you‚Äôre thinking about trying this app, just be careful ‚Äî and set a calendar reminder to cancel. You won‚Äôt get one from them.

title: HelloHabit - Habit Tracker
content:
This app is generally really good and it‚Äôs helped me a lot since getting it. But there‚Äôs one pretty significant feature missing, and it‚Äôs an option to pause habits and not lose your streak. For example if you become sick or go on a vacation and you can‚Äôt follow your regular habits and routine. It makes me feel guilty for losing my streaks, but like sometimes your routine has routine has to change for a few days! I feel like this would be fairly easy to implement and would make the app almost perfect to me. 

A way to set goals to be for a set amount of time (like exercising for 30 min for example) but still be able to check it off just once and not have to check off all the minutes would also be great. If my goal is to exercise for 30 min, I‚Äôm gonna do it all at once. I don‚Äôt want to have the click the check mark a bunch of times to get to it completed. 

If those two features were added it would be a perfect 5 stars to me!

2 - you can‚Äôt archive habits. So if you have a short term goal you‚Äôre working on, once it‚Äôs completed you either have to delete it or just have it cluttering the screen. Another major con for me.

title: Blokd - App Blocker
content:
I like how this app is cheaper for what you get than the leading competitor, and it was what convinced me to get it. Keep in mind that the website advertises this app as a ‚Äúsubscription free‚Äù service but thats not 100% accurate. Upon initial download, it actually charged $10/m or $60 a yr to allow all apps to be blocked but allowed for exceptions, whereas the free version required you to manually select which apps to block, with a max of 50. 

It seems that they have recently adjusted that number according to their changelog. I think for transparency, you (the customer) should be aware that this payment gate exists somewhere in the app. I don‚Äôt know if the leading competitor also has a hidden paywall because they too advertise no subscription fees.

Other than that hiccup, this app is incredible and works perfectly with a clean and easy to use UI. The Bloks themselves take a little finagling to register that I would expect will be easier to lock/unlock with practice.

title: Blokd - App Blocker
content:
I received my blok 2 weeks ago, and it‚Äôs already been game changing. My screen time is down, and I feel happier and more focused. 

It‚Äôs so clever. Because think about it: temporarily blocking apps on your phone is easy to do, but just as easy to undo. We‚Äôve all tried it and quickly given up. The temptation to use some apps again is too strong, and I always fall back into that trap. It truly takes discipline. But the thing about owning this blok is that it‚Äôs actually forced me to become more disciplined. With blok, I can have a physical barrier and better enforce my app limitations in a way that I can‚Äôt easily fall into temptations to open them again. It‚Äôs purposely harder to do that, and that‚Äôs the key here.

It‚Äôs the perfect solution for this problem, and I really wish I had my blok years ago. It‚Äôs the little push I needed to finally make this change in my life.

title: Superhappy Screen Time Blocker
content:
so, before this app, i used screenzen and opal. opal i used when ai coaches weren't paywalled, and it was mostly good, but the blocking was done in sessions, so there was nothing to stop me from binging in between them. screenzen had a lot of neat features, but what i really needed wasn't a block screen, it was to be actively discouraged from using it. 
when you have a serious addiction to an app (mine is tiktok) mindfulness exercises and long block screens only get you so far. having to talk to the ai and actually justify whether or not i absolutely need to open something has already been a huge barrier between me and mindlessly opening it. ive been using the drill sergeant and it's so so helpful! i love that you can also modify how it behaves towards you. i made my sergeant a bit stricter in tone, because a little bit of curtness is a lot more discouraging and really makes you consider if you absolutely must open it. highly recommend!!

author: 2.24467E+15

title: Superhappy Screen Time Blocker
content:
I initially got Superhappy to help cut down on my screen time, and it‚Äôs been great for that. But what really surprised me is how much it‚Äôs helped with other habits, too. I used to order takeout from apps like Postmates and GrubHub 2-3 times a day, but since using Superhappy, I haven‚Äôt ordered once. It‚Äôs actually helped me stop late-night food orders and made me more motivated to cook at home.

What I love most is how the app is there at just the right time‚Äîwhen I‚Äôm opening a social media app out of boredom or when I‚Äôm thinking about ordering food. It‚Äôs like a gentle reminder that I don‚Äôt really need to, and it helps me stay on track.

Honestly, I think Superhappy could be used for more than just screen time. It has the potential to change how people use their phones in a bigger way by helping them build healthier habits overall.

One suggestion I have is maybe adding more options when it comes to blocking apps. For example, I enjoy playing chess, but I can get frustrated when I lose. It would be cool if Superhappy could remind me to stay cool and enjoy the game instead of fully blocking the app.

Overall, Superhappy has really made a difference in my daily life, and I‚Äôd recommend it to anyone looking to create better phone habits.
author: Justbeian

title: Superhappy Screen Time Blocker
content:
Ai model is outdated, effective enough for simple conversations, but cannot handle context or memory well. 

Developers want $75/year to use their app to block more than one app on your phone, significantly more than what their competitors charge.

There are many easy ways around getting apps unlocked. For those who need serious deterrence from using their problem apps, it will not be adequate. 

My recommendation, for those who are serious about blocking their phone: I have been using the ‚Äòfreedom‚Äô app for about a month now (I‚Äôm not getting paid to say this). It cost $40 for a year, and is much much much more effective at limiting what apps I can use and when. While it does lack the same ability to have a conversation to unlock your apps, there is still a function to unlock apps for a certain amount of time, or you can take that away from yourself.

So while I think this app has its place for those who don‚Äôt want serious limits and don‚Äôt mind paying extra, it is definitely not the best product on the market, in my opinion. 

TL;DR: Superhappy doesn‚Äôt allow you to truly block your apps and is overpriced. Check out the freedom app and others.

title: Superhappy Screen Time Blocker
content: no, seriously. this app has helped me curb almost all of my scrolling habits. I was spending 6+ hours a DAY on my phone, and now I‚Äôm down to about an hour and that‚Äôs mostly for work and emails now. It still requires discipline not to ask for unlocks but that extra mindful step is exactly the space needed in order to break scrolling habits. I am so grateful. If you‚Äôre anything like me and having trouble separating yourself from your phone to live your LIFE, give this app a try. The paid service is worth every penny. Thank you for developing this app!!

content: Horrible. Actually horrible. (Well, if you‚Äôre broke and don‚Äôt have money like me.) It costs 7$ a month for an app. For an app thats absurd imo. Why promote something as free then when it comes to free only give 3 days free? There‚Äôs not even a normal version of it, so it‚Äôs money all together. I wish there was just one app like this that was free bro üòî. But there are alternatives if you would like a free way of getting rid of apps. You could set a screen time for your apps,  Or you could delete them. But yeah good idea not the right advertisement. (I saw you took 3 months to get to someone‚Äôs reply, I‚Äôm not asking to answer this right away, but I would like an answer soon.) Thank you and have a nice day!
author: Carson_alvarez

title: Superhappy Screen Time Blocker
content:
This app is meant to create a barrier from opening apps you‚Äôve registered as ‚Äúdistracting‚Äù during time blocks you‚Äôve setup. It does that somewhat effectively since you have to have a low effort argument with a chatbot to use those apps during those blocks. 

Where this app fails is with the goal setting and its tracking of your app usage- it only tracks the time you‚Äôve requested for unlocks, not your actual screen time with say Instagram. So the stats it collects are inaccurate at best, meaningless at worst. 

Great app if you want to make it harder to open an app like Instagram- you will have to argue with a chatbot every single time. 

I think I‚Äôm going to request a refund.

author: uSoul_

title: Superhappy Screen Time Blocker
content:
In the words of that one strokes album, is this it?

yeah, this is it. 

for most of my life, I had hoped for technology to evolve so that it became self limiting because according to dudes that were kind of big brain, but also racist like, Kant, too much freedom is not a good thing. Creativity needs discipline and discipline needs limits. 

Do not kid yourself, unless you were a freak of nature, you do not use your phone and appropriate amount. 

I think all of us in an ideal world would like to be free from the phone. I think we would all be better. People were legitimately comfortable with the chatter and silence of our own minds. 

The closest you will come to using your phone appropriately will likely be a direct result of using this app. 

It requires reflection because it necessitates that you have a dialogue about what you are doing.

To live a life of comfort in this age where our attention has become a commodity, you must design a structure for consumption in your life.  

This is it‚Ä¶

title: Website & App Blocker | Atten
content:
I've been using this app for a little bit, and I can say that it's really good. There's another popular app called [Well, I won't say its name]. There are other apps in this space.

What really makes this app shine is its beautiful UI and blocking your apps (which a lot of other apps on the App Store do) in a very nice way, allowing you to take breaks, which is really nice. Not only does it have a scheduling feature (basically required for an app like this), but it also allows you to control adding breaks and controlling the strictness of the breaks.

Really good app, great job with it! The only issue (not really big) is that some of the more advanced features are gated behind an $80 lifetime subscription. But it seems to me that you don't need those features, so the app is not really lacking. Five stars!

title: DuckDuckGo Browser, Search, AI
content:
Oct 2025 update. 

AI still won't work in landscape, meaning I can't use my normal keyboard. 

+++

Latest update has videos still playing audio AFTER the tab is closed. Every "upgrade" is a break. 

++++

Latest "update": refresh button removed, replaced with share button. Fail upon fail. 

+++
Every update of this browser I have to see what has broken this time. The latest is the Back button loses where you were on the previous page. Hot garbage for X in the browser. Other browsers still work fine; it's not an X change, it's a DDG fail. 

Other changes are less annoying but still very annoying, like changing the placement and size if back/cancel buttons for URLs. Favorites icons are trashed. Again. 

If you enjoy frivolous changes that degrade your experience every few weeks, this is the browser for you!

title: Parental Control App - Kidsee
content:
The app is very good and simple to use, but it would be great if some improvements were made. I need additional features to enhance its functionality.
	1.	App Blocking Feature: I would like the ability to block specific apps for my child or allow only one app at a time. However, sometimes the app behaves incorrectly‚Äîfor example, when I select an allowed app, it ends up blocking everything. On the other hand, when I choose to allow only system apps, it permits all apps instead. This behavior should be corrected to work as expected.
	2.	Homework Time Display Issue: When I set ‚ÄúHomework Time‚Äù for my child, the app does not display it correctly. Instead, no matter what schedule I create, it always shows ‚ÄúBedtime‚Äù to the child. It would be great if the app could properly display ‚ÄúHomework Time‚Äù when selected.

I appreciate your efforts in developing this app and hope these issues can be resolved in future updates.

I originally rate this app a 1. I‚Äôm changing my rating of this app because of the quick responses from the support team. 
‚ÄúRecently it wiped every event, due dates, appointments, off the app. It‚Äôs the only place I had stored that information so I immediately contacted them. It was easily fixed by logging out & logging back in. However, now I am logged out with no way of logging back in. The app shows an error message saying that I have no network even though i do‚Äù
That being said the app is very clear and concise. It is my go to for be productive and staying on top of class work. The prompt responses for support make it a worthy product despite the glitches.

author: dhdydudud

title: Productivity - Daily Planner
content:
This truly is the very best application to plan and manage your life. I upgraded to the Pro version after only a week of using it.

I have been using this app for about a year now, and this latest update is very beautiful!

There are still a few tweaks/implementations that need to be addressed:
- Remove the login screen whenever we load the app.
- Morning Routines, Daily Checkin, and Reflection reminders do not work properly. I set the time to be different than the default time, but it kept on reminding me at the app's default set time.
- Routines that are tied to a Major Goal do not automatically go away after the goal has been achieved; it remained as a weekly routine indefinitely.
*** Adjusting the routines' time and days of the week does not sync up with the Calendar app; we have to manually edit those times and days on the Calendar app as well if whenever we make adjustment to the routine. I must say that this lack of sync function had irritated me the most, as making minor changes and adjustments to our routines are important to making progress toward our goals. The end-goal should be fixed, but the routines to get there should be flexible.

Even with all the weak points mentioned above (which could be improved in future updates), I still would rate this app as a 5 Stars app. It is definitely one of the most important apps on my iPhone.

I highly recommend anyone that is serious in personal development to purchase the Pro version of this app. It will definitely produce positive changes to your life, if you make a daily habit of using it!

title: Strides: Habit Tracker + Goals
content: This is a pretty nice tracking app for developing habits. However, the free version is limited to only 3 goals, so I‚Äôm on the search for a different app. I work in human services, which means I earn a low income *and* have student loan debt. $4.99/month or $79.99 for lifetime subscription seems overpriced for a few kilobytes of storage. The developers have been providing the same response for years regarding their subscription model, stating it‚Äôs sustainable. But it‚Äôs not sustainable for customers. Subscriptions add up quickly, and an individual customer only has so much income for companies to eat up each month. [‚ÄúFor the price of a latte‚Äù won‚Äôt work in this instance, as I (and many others) don‚Äôt have income to waste at coffee shops.] I‚Äôve used this app for years to track various projects and habits. But I don‚Äôt rely on it by any means. Would I consider it ‚Äúlife-changing‚Äù and worth repeatedly carving out a piece of my income for it, or worth giving up 1-2 weeks of groceries for a lifetime subscription? No.

title: Foqos
content:
I originally was looking into purchasing a Brick but was pretty disgusted to see them charge 50$ for a cheaply encased RFID tag which you can buy for less than 1$ each on Amazon.

This app does everything it says it does and works flawlessly, and even does more than Brick since you can set up your own RFID tags and even use QR codes if you don‚Äôt want to buy any tags. 

My only feedback is to add an option to search for apps when selecting apps to block, and give the option to see all apps and sort by name to make it easier to find a specific app. 

These devs are awesome and got an instant donation.

title: Foqos
content: It feels like a breath of fresh air to find an app that is designed well, functions properly, is actively maintained, isn‚Äôt bombarded with ads or constant paywalls, and this checks all of the boxes. That‚Äôs it. Also, if you have a 3D printer, I highly recommend printing an enclosure for the NFC tags to make it more convenient! One feature that may be useful is an emergency override, but make it annoying to use, so it can‚Äôt be used whenever, like waiting 10 minutes, only allowing it once, etc. But other than that, this app is amazing!

title: Buddhify: Guided Meditation
content:
This app it truly amazing. I don‚Äôt use it nearly as much as I should and I don‚Äôt use it to all its functionality. However, I use the different sleep meditations to help me get a goodnight sleep and wind down and it has made a huge difference in my happiness and life in general.  Let me explain‚Ä¶

Side note:  I,  on occasion, have a really hard time falling asleep despite being very tired and wanting so bad to sleep. Before this app, my sleep problems would keep me up all. Night until I pass out from exhaustion.  Let me give a real example‚Ä¶ 

I was having one of the worst times falling asleep a couple weeks ago the night before I took my midterm for a summer class that would make or break my entire fall schedule. It ended up being about 5 am after restored attempts to fall asleep I  finally remembered I had the app and boom it worked! The guided sleep meditation allowed me to put anxiety aside and the calming voice just eased me into sleep.

I really and truly can not recommend this app enough. If you have ever had trouble with sleep look no further the app is well worth it and there is so much more to it then just helping you fall asleep!

It‚Äôs also very set it and forget it, only once in a couple of months will i go in and toggle or change something.
The meh:
Adding exceptions is a nice feature but can be finnicky at times. I don‚Äôt blame the app for this i don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs a better way to do this on mobile. 
Youtube‚Äôs app has the ads baked in so much that you will still get ads even with this adblocker (you can block the ads with exceptions but the videos will stop loading too) BUT the adblocker WORKS on the browser version of youtube so i just stopped using the app altogether and use the ad-free broswer version.
The cons(?): if i understand how this adblocker works, it redirects ALL your phone‚Äôs data requests through their servers where it blocks certain url‚Äôs from sending data back to your phone. That does mean that theoretically the app makers see ALL your data. Depending on how you feel about this it‚Äôs either a dealbreaker or an afterthought. I am already in too far so i just trust them at this point not to misuse my personal info.

title: Flat Tomato (Time Management)
content:
Solid little app. Birds chirping at break times is a nice touch. 

I am adding new info to this review, of the paid version. 

I feel I am more productive and focused as a result of using this app. I have integrated it with my calendar (it required an email to the developer to figure out how to do so), and it is nice to see my Pomodoro's appear on my calendar as a sign of work well done. 

In my previous review (see below), I said that I did not use this often. I am using it more now. And getting more things done. 

A couple of items that are puzzling to me: the awards and feedback and are you cons of stars and moons are not clear to me. 

Also, sometimes the sound cuts out, or the select task option (below the clock on main screen) disappears. Those are minor cosmetic issues that don't stop the app from working very well, but do detract from the final polish of the app. 

Finally, this app asks me to review it. So I finally did‚Ä¶ And find that I DID review it earlier. Ah well.

OLD COMMENTS ABOUT OLD VERSION: I don't use it daily, or even nearly daily, but do use it as a mental reboot aid at times when I've been too distracted. It's excellent to help me get on task/stay on task. Also good for getting started on or working through imposing tasks or things I am mentally resisting. 

I upgraded for the calendar tracking list of tasks.

title: Brainbuddy: Quit Porn Now
content: I have struggled with online addiction since I was a boy. When I was 10yrs old, my wannabe rocker father introduced me to that world because he thought it was ‚Äúcool‚Äù and ‚Äúwhat guys do.‚Äù Over time I was afraid of how it was making me feel, and I asked him and my mother to put parental controls on our home computer. They both refused. I‚Äôm 26 now, and I have battled this off and on the entire time. Sometimes I‚Äôd get away from it for months, years, but it kept coming back. This app helped me get away from it once, and during a recent relapse it is helping me get away from it again. What I love about the app is the outreach and support it offers from like-struggling people. You are anonymously together in your fight and able to encourage each other through an issue so difficult to seek encouragement and support for in your day to day life. The application costs a little money to utilize, but it is a small price to pay compared to the cost of addiction. Act now. Fix it now. Any day you spend carrying that guilt and shame is a day wasted. Rise above. Be better.

author: AvidClashHater

title: Brainbuddy: Quit Porn Now
content:
Brainbuddy was exactly what I needed when I first began the fight against porn addiction. In the early stages, the app gave me structure, daily check-ins, and encouragement that helped build the discipline I didn‚Äôt yet have on my own. It tracked my streaks, gave insightful content, and helped me reflect on my urges without shame.

What I appreciate most is that Brainbuddy doesn‚Äôt just focus on stopping porn ‚Äî it helps you understand yourself better, build healthier habits, and improve your mindset.

Over time, my journey became more spiritual and personal. I started turning to prayer, reading books, and speaking to God in sujood instead of relying on numbers. But that‚Äôs a sign the app worked ‚Äî it helped me graduate from external motivation to internal strength.

If you‚Äôre starting your journey, this app is a powerful ally. Use it, reflect, grow ‚Äî and when you‚Äôre ready to walk without it, do so with gratitude. That‚Äôs what I‚Äôm doing now.

author: ChrysD21

author: Pineapple 4

title: Mindfulness Coach
content:
I‚Äôve read many books, watched many videos and have taught an Eckhart Tolle group of over 200 k people online daily for 4-5 years. This app, hands down is the best tool to step into mindfulness with, beginners or advanced. If Tolle, Donald Walsh etc and nonduality is not getting you anywhere or even if it has, try this. This app is FREE. The people who made this app didn‚Äôt make it to monetize off of. They‚Äôve made it to be effective and it is exactly that, effective. You just might be really pleasantly surprised.

The only thing that I would like to see fixed is the counter that keeps track of how many days in a row you use the app. It doesn‚Äôt work a lot of times, maybe it is to do with change of month and new year. 

I have used this app every day for almost 4 months and the counter keeps resetting. 

Other than this very minor issue it is hands down the very best mindfulness app that I‚Äôve used over the years. There are also links in the app to get more free exercises that are really awesome as well from iRest. Do yourself a favor and try this app. 

Just because it‚Äôs free doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs poorly designed or that it doesn‚Äôt work as well as other mindfulness apps. I have several apps including Wake Up and this one is just as good and effective as that expensive app. 

One other thing that I would love to see covered by this app is ‚Äúnon-striving and non-doing‚Äù. If these are understood mindfulness is a cake walk. It is also the same as Wu Wei non-striving and non-doing. Everything that we need is right here in this moment, anything else is a desire and is mind-made suffering because we struggle to achieve a goal in the hopes that when we get to that goal we‚Äôll be happy or when ‚ÄúI retire‚Äù I‚Äôll be happy or when ‚ÄúI hit the lotto, I‚Äôll be happy‚Äù. 

All those goals that we rely on to make us happy in a future moment is like having a stick with a carrot dangling out in front of us, and we constantly try to catch it or get to, not realizing that the chasing after it, is what creates a LOT of suffering AND takes us away from this moment. 

If we can see this and intentionally just Stop chasing a future moment and be Here Now, we can have peace, joy and contentment. It really is that simple. 

Thank you so much to the developers and VA for making this free and available to everyone, veteran or civilian. üôèüèºüôèüèº‚ù§Ô∏è

author: vzuom

title: Forest: Focus for Productivity
content:
I‚Äôve had this app since 2017 and used it on and off through college and my working life. It‚Äôs one of the best apps on my phone, and I don‚Äôt regret paying for it back then. 

Pros: the tree variety is great, especially within the past year with the new monthly challenge plant varieties. The ambient sounds are good. The graphs are great if you use tags and unobtrusive if you don‚Äôt. It has a lot of small quality of life features that are really great, like the ability to keep the screen on so you can see the timer running, the ability to run a whitelist of apps in case you need to consult something on your phone quickly without your plant dying, and the fact that you can set the app to keep counting time length. The achievement system helps newbies quickly diversify tree species available to them. The new daily challenges award a small amount of the paid currency so with patience you can unlock previous time limited trees. It‚Äôs also significantly spread up collecting gold, which is nice for a casual like me. Most of the tree species have stages of growth depending on how long you plant them, so even with only a few trees to start with you can get some visual interest going. I like planting a variety of the more realistic trees so my little monthly forest is biodiverse, but I appreciate there‚Äôs also weird and whimsical trees. There really is a tree or two for everyone.

Cons: The company behind this app has decided to monetize it more, in the form of a paid subscription model instead of a one-time purchase. I understand why they‚Äôre doing this, and I think it‚Äôs going to be good for the app, but on principle I won‚Äôt be using it as I dislike subscription models for productivity apps. Hopefully the free version won‚Äôt be too inaccessible. Also, the daily challenge prize collection glitches sometimes, and it‚Äôs not actually clear on the screen where to tap to collect it and move on.

Wishlist: Like another commenter, I‚Äôd really like the ability to set a little chime when a planting is done that makes it through silent mode. I always have my phone on silent though so maybe this is on me! Other than that, some more water based plants would be nice. I‚Äôd love the ability to put a little pond on my forest. The app also has some integration with the Apple Watch but I‚Äôd also love something like a quick replant button on the watch that starts the same tree and timer combo again.
author: tahrao

title: Focus Keeper - Pomodoro Timer
content:
I have used this app for years now as a pro subscriber and it‚Äôs been great, but recent updates have caused a variety of bugs which are making it useless at the moment. First, it was slow to load, some of the UI was changed and timers started counting up instead of down, etc. 
I uninstalled and reinstalled and those issues seem to be fixed now, but others persist. Namely, notification sounds seem to only work half the time at most, and I get banner notifications that seem to have no connection to my use of the app. For instance I last used the app this morning and closed it out afterwards, but all day today I keep getting notifications saying ‚Äúyour focus session ended!‚Äù or ‚Äúshort break has ended, get back to work!‚Äù and is showing I‚Äôm on session 31 out of 12, so it must be counting and logging sessions even though the app is closed. The same thing happened yesterday. This, and the inconsistent sounds at the end of sessions means it‚Äôs impossible to use the app to reliably track focus sessions!

title: Parental Control App - Kidslox
content: So much better than arguing with kids.  They don‚Äôt do what they need to do, you shut down the distractions.  They need access to the internet but not YouTube- done. If they finish the task before it shuts down, you simply cancel the shut down.  Bed time schedules make the kids associate shut down with time not you.  There‚Äôs been quirky things here and there but to be honest, the creators have been on top of remedying them and responding in a manner typical app creators don‚Äôt. author: Luisramonvg

title: Influenster: Try & Review
content:
I used to enjoy this app a lot before a lot of the changes have been made, which I feel was unwarranted for. I used to love see the badges for products I reviewed - now that‚Äôs gone. Right now, they focus on claim nows mostly, and while I‚Äôve been able to snag some, I feel that they keep offering me things that don‚Äôt align with my interests. I‚Äôve been working hard in putting out authentic reviews and reviewing things I‚Äôve personally purchased and it‚Äôs not helping with anything any more. 

Like some others have said - if you don‚Äôt fit into their mold, you won‚Äôt get anything. They‚Äôre extremely biased in who they give things to, and I‚Äôve noticed if you‚Äôre a POC, you won‚Äôt get as much offers as opposed to if you were white. I usually see on Reddit and Instagram of people who get multiple claims daily or weekly, and its always a very similar group of people. What‚Äôs worse is that sometimes they give reviews like ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt wait to try this!‚Äù like hello? You were sent the product to test it? Some of these reviews come off really fake. But who cares if Influenster doesn‚Äôt care, am I right?

I never get notifications for claim now nor does the app bother to offer me anything new. I also see some people getting really big ticket items and always wondered if I would get a chance. I have been on the app for over 3 years now, and I‚Äôm in mid to late 20s, so I don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôm doing wrong. I‚Äôve settled that Influenster would never offer me these things given my demographics, and have put less effort into this app compared to what I‚Äôve done in the past. 

I‚Äôve also seen some disturbing posts of people selling ozempic through comments and the fact Influenster is doing nothing to remove these accounts gets concerning. 

Last but not least, I used to get my items within a week of claim. Now I‚Äôm lucky if I even get them within the month.

author: lindabaja

title: Sattva Meditations & Mantras
content: This app has a number of good things going for it. It has a clean look and interface, the dashboard and tracking is very useful, and it doesn‚Äôt feel as gimmicky as other platforms. However, there are some simple key features missing. First, the heart rate tracking is either too difficult to use or just doesn‚Äôt work. Given the number of heart rate trackers on the market now, heart rate data via a smartwatch or other device is way overdue. Second, the timer feature only lets you use either their preselected sounds (which interrupt your meditation by cutting in and out to buffer) and your music library. For those who use Spotify, you are out of luck. Third, also in the timer feature, when the timer ends, the sound abruptly cuts out. It is very jarring to go from your relaxing meditative sound to an abrupt silence. Even if you use a bell to mark the end of the mediation, the ending is abrupt and disturbs some of the mindfulness you were just building. Simply allowing the sounds to continue after the bell (even at a reduced volume) would greatly improve the experience. Overall, good app, but needs improvements before it can be considered the best choice.

title: Be Focused Pro - Focus Timer
content: I love this app, I use it daily! Time management is my Achilles heel, so being able to visually see the time winding down has been really nice. My favorite feature is probably the minute increment alerts that sound like ticks, they‚Äôre super helpful for keeping me on track if I‚Äôm listening to anything with headphones and away from my phone. It‚Äôs really nice because I don‚Äôt have to be using my phone to still get the time-minding reminders I need. Finally this app has been a game changer for me with intimidating tasks. Setting a timer has been a great way for me to break through that initial anxiety and just get started. Breaking down tasks into manageable parts with this app has helped me be both more efficient and effective, so I would suggest it to anyone who could use some help with time management! I used to be embarrassed to use a timer for this purpose because all the reviews made it seem like it was just for kids, but let me tell you I think that ANYONE would benefit from this app if they would like to manage their time more effectively. Definitely worth the money in my opinion ‚ò∫Ô∏è

author: Raising3kids

title: Parental Control App - OurPact
content:
‚Ä¶but it just didn‚Äôt do what I needed it to do. I wanted to give my son an hour of screen time each day, and I wanted it automated through OurPact so I didn‚Äôt have to be the bad guy and on top of it constantly. Specifically, wanted him to be able to listen to an hour of music or podcasts. Unfortunately, OurPact‚Äôs shut-off mechanism doesn‚Äôt work for audio: if a user turns on music with their time allotment, but turns off the screen, the time they spend listening doesn‚Äôt count against the allowance. After just a couple days I realized my son was on his headphones longer than an hour (and he sure wasn‚Äôt going to point it out to me!). I got in touch with the company to ask for help, and this was their response:

‚ÄúThis particular issue is a bit of a challenge for us since it's related to Apple product functionality and how iOS devices report applications to our software. We hope to have a fix for this in a future update... 
 
In the meantime, we suggest you send a manual 'Grant' to your child's device, then after a few minutes send a manual 'Block'. 
 
This should shut them out of Spotify or whatever app they were trying to access. They may try again, but from our experience, usually, they give up pretty quickly and decide just to call it quits.‚Äù

I had suspected it was an Apple thing, not an Out Pact thing, but I had hope. Here‚Äôs how I responded:

‚ÄúIn response to your suggestion: "we suggest you send a manual 'Grant' to your child's device, then after a few minutes send a manual 'Block'." This is exactly why we got OurPact in the first place: to do away with the need for "granting" anything. As a parent trying to keep my kids safe online, I am making myself insane trying to give my kids an hour of screen time *OR* listening time each day. When it is me who is getting asked for time, and me who is setting a timer for an hour, and me who is disabling the kids' devices when an hour is up, I take on a part-time job as a police officer. I don't know about you, but as a parent I have to be the bad guy plenty enough already. If, on the other hand, the device was set up automatically to give an hour of screen/listening time when the child wants it, to count down and shut off automatically, it would offer me peace of mind *AND* not require my engagement. Win-win! 

So....if that's not something OurPact can do, then I'd like my money back. Because that's definitely how you promoted it.‚Äù

After that, I‚Äôve pinged OurPact twice but they haven‚Äôt responded, and I haven‚Äôt received a refund. I‚Äôm especially unhappy about this because setting the app up on my son‚Äôs phone was outrageously invasive and time-consuming. 

I don‚Äôt know that there‚Äôs any real solution to this problem out there yet. Not OurPact‚Äôs fault, but they need to be clear on the limitations in their advertising.

content:
This app would be acceptable if it were free, but for a paid app, I expect more. 

1) Setting up notifications is difficult and requires a separate step outside of setting up the task. The notifications should be able to be set up per sub task. It would be better if you could edit a task and set a notification time for each sub task. 
2) Notifications are not reliable on Apple Watch. I only get a 2 notifications per day on a task with 5 sub tasks. 
3) If I complete all sub tasks early in the day, I still get notifications later in the day. Having the ability to add a notification time per sub task might help solve this as the notifications would not be completely separate from the tasks themselves. 
4) I can‚Äôt figure out how to edit a future task. I can only edit tasks that are scheduled for the current day. 

I love the idea of this app but it is missing a huge amount of polish.

author: WDWinship

title: MultiTimer: Multiple timers
content:
I tried several other timer apps only to be left disappointed. This app however, I paid for the pro version because I believe this app is very promising and the best experience I‚Äôve had so far.

What I love so far from this app: 
1. love that I can set the ‚ÄúALERT auto repeat‚Äù to constantly repeat itself. This is helpful in times when I have to setup away from my phones and alarm goes off repeatedly and when I get back I am reminded that time‚Äôs up. Unlike another timer I downloaded prior to this, it only ring once and if I am away from my phone then I just missed the reminder and lose track of time as that timer then goes into another continuous loop.
2. Love that I can set the ‚ÄúTIMER‚Äù to auto repeat. Ie. I set my reminder to drink my water every hour without having to reset or do anything!
3. Love the user interface and the ability to see everything all on one screen without having to scroll through to find what I want. It‚Äôs like the screen adjust itself to accommodate for all my different timers I keep adding - all on one screen! 
4. love the ability to have different timers running at different intervals. Ie. If I am working on something that should take 1 hour, but need to break it down then I can set different timers for that and run it all at the same time (Ie. 5 min, 15 min, 7 min, etc‚Ä¶) 

What I would love to see:
1. The ability for the app to act like an alarm even if the phone volume is turned off. I don‚Äôt always like to have my phone on for a reason or sometimes forget to turn my phone volume back on in the morning, but then I would miss the reminders on this app. Of course there would need to be a way for people to turn on/off this function because it may not work for everyone. 
2. Wish that there‚Äôs a way to still see the timer from my phone while the screen is turned off. 
3. Ringer does not work when using EarPods. 

I see great potential for this app as long as developers continue to work on improving and making it better. So far I am really loving this app and no need to look further.
author: genesis 2018

title: MultiTimer: Multiple timers
content:
Not only does it allow stacking multiple timers, it also has different timer styles like multi-step and multi-phase timers, and even a pomodoro mode too. The wide range of customization is a great touch. 

My only real issue is the Watch app, it hides all boards with containers in them and I wasn't informed of this shortcoming until I deduced why some of my boards were not appearing. The lack of unique notification sound for watchOS notifications also makes it easy to mistake for the notifications of other apps (like, say, an annoying Discord user using the @everyone ping) and thus ignore by mistake. So I end up just not bothering with the Watch app and just stick to having this app's notifications ring on my phone. 

As a phone-only app, it's still quite stellar though and I much prefer it even as Apple makes very small improvements to their own timer app.

That extra 3% is covered by the web-facing display of the various timers on offer here.

The only real improvement I could think of is having this timer hover over the display on iPad and Mac instances such that it could remain on screen when iterating through other tools. title: MultiTimer: Multiple timers
content:
I wanted a stopwatch app where I could set up multiple stopwatches so I could track the time when I‚Äôm mentally focused vs distracted. Additionally, I wanted to have two large buttons for these stopwatches. MultiTimer does just that and lets me add more if I want to. It‚Äôs very customizable. I also love that I can then take this data and export it as a CSV file.

Improvements:

Currently, the stopwatch starts when you press a button. Then it pauses if you hit it again. Finally, it resets the third time you hit the button
Personally, I wish there was an option to customize this sequence. I wish I could just hit the button to start, and hit it a 2nd time to reset it. I don‚Äôt really care what time it measures because I‚Äôll be analyzing it later.

One more thing I wish was possible is to ‚ÄúLink‚Äù multiple timers. For example, If I stop watch #1, watch number #2 automatically starts.

Again these are just personal preferences but the app is still pretty great.

title: MultiTimer: Multiple timers
content: This app is great, and I use it in my personal life, but it was exceptionally useful for me when working in the healthcare field. I would label and color my timers with patient rooms (e.g., ‚ÄúRoom 1‚Äù and the timer is displayed in the color bright blue), and I‚Äôd select an icon indicating the treatment modality to me (e.g., silhouette of a head with a gear in the brain), and I could easily set the timer for the duration of the patient‚Äôs TMS (neuromodulation) treatment protocol, so I would know exactly when I must be in each patient‚Äôs room to initiate their next treatment protocol. And because I also monitored patients being treated using a different treatment modality (Spravato) on other days, I had additional timers - which utilized different colors and icons - for monitoring those patients. Healthcare Technicians would sometimes had 8 handheld timers with sticky notes on a desk. With a busy clinic schedule, this kept me precise and punctual in my patient care.

title: Focus - Timer for Productivity
content:
When you really have to focus on a task, this is the app to help you get it done. Based on the Pomodoro method, instead of working for hours and hours on end, you do work, take a break, do work, take a break, etc. By default, you would work for 25 minutes and take a 5 minute break. After four sessions are complete, you are rewarded with a longer 20 minute break. Additionally, you can keep a list of your tasks needed to be done, check them off and view a history of the tasks and sessions you‚Äôve completed. 

This app works great on iPhone and ever better on the Apple Watch. I can use the Apple Watch app to quickly see how much time is remaining in my session/break and also pause the timer.

title: Focus - Timer for Productivity
content: Saw that this was watch compatible, and downloaded it for that reason. Perhaps that support only started with watchOS 6, but I find that doubtful since it was only made available (to s√©ries 3 and above) a few days ago. As watchOS 6 is not yet available for Series 1 & 2 watches, I‚Äôm unable to download and use it with my watch. Disappointing. While it‚Äôs important for developers to keep up to date with OS updates, and I would otherwise appreciate the timeliness, there‚Äôs no reason to drop support for a previous version of an OS when it‚Äôs not yet available for all devices that will support it. Glad I have not yet paid for this app. I don‚Äôt mind the subscription fee, as I understand the work involved in app maintenance and development, but I would have been livid if I‚Äôd been a paying subscriber and support for my watch was dropped before the watchOS update became available for me. Not exactly a fair way to handle things IMO.

author: ChefYensid

title: Productive - Habit Tracker
content:
I think there should be a feature where you can mark that a habit was not completed. There is a feature where you can skip a habit in special occasions, and there is a feature where you can mark that a habit was completed. I understand that if you don‚Äôt do either of these then the app recognizes it as an incomplete habit but sometimes when I go back to previous days and see that a habit is not completed, I can‚Äôt remember if I just forgot to mark it as complete or if I actually didn‚Äôt do it. That‚Äôs why I really think there should be a feature to mark that a habit was not completed instead of just having that be recognized by the app if you don‚Äôt mark it at all. I don‚Äôt want to just skip a habit and have it say that my streak continues. I benefit from the punishment of losing a streak. That‚Äôs why I want there to be an additional feature to mark that a habit was not completed. Maybe it could be a long press on the habit or some other type of gesture. 

Thank you for your time and for considering this feature. Other than this feature, I would actually give five stars‚Äîbut this is a huge issue for me that is make or break for me.

author: Ibis 1357

title: Happier Meditation
content:
This app started out great. I still use it every day and have for years, but I really thought about not renewing this February when my annual subscription came due. But I saw that it had rebranded as ‚ÄúHappier‚Äú so I decided to give it a chance. 

I didn‚Äôt realize that founder and creative force Dan Harris left over creative differences. I don‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs why I dislike the new stuff on the app so much, but it doesn‚Äôt seem to actually understand mindfulness anymore. And some of the content is squishy and would never have been allowed by Dan. There are these video shorts of people getting interrupted in their daily life and then explaining how they try to be mindful in that moment, and they just don‚Äôt work.

I miss Dan‚Äôs podcast episodes. I found the new video course almost unwatchable. Because I‚Äôve still got nine more months., I will keep an eye on the app to see if it improves. But I suspect I will be sticking with the Waking Up app and the Plum Village app and dumping this one. There doesn‚Äôt seem to be a vision anymore. I‚Äôm no longer learning or growing by interacting with this.

content: By the end of lesson five I was changed permanently. I never knew it could be this simple. Extreme, intense emotions my entire life are now just gone. The weight is gone. The load is lifted.
