author: AppleUser676534677

title: Happier Meditation
content: A key tenet of Buddhism is learning to sit with things that are unpleasant and let them go. That is now my experience with this app. Gone is the serendipity of finding a daily meditation that you didn‚Äôt know was exactly what you needed. Instead I get an AI curated list of meditations like ‚Äúdealing with rage‚Äù and ‚Äúa depressed day‚Äù. Those are not issues I‚Äôm dealing with so if they had come up as generic options for everyone I would have just moved along. But now those are the options chosen FOR ME specifically. I realize it‚Äôs just a machine and not a person accusing me of rage issues, but it still is unpleasant. Maybe they‚Äôre trying to give me rage issues!! :) It used to be nice to read the weekly wisdom. That is gone. The fact that the developer says it‚Äôs available on the website is useless to me when I‚Äôm meditating on my phone. It does feel like the whole thing has moved from being something health promoting for people to something designed for data collecting and optimizing corporate profits. I won‚Äôt be renewing.

title: Happier Meditation
content:
I used to like this app a lot - open it up and it offered a ten-minute meditation for the day. I liked that I didn‚Äôt have to choose something, I could just go with the default. After a couple of years it seemed like there weren‚Äôt many new meditations though, and now, recent updates have changed the app considerably, where I can‚Äôt even get to the meditations until after ‚Äúchecking in‚Äù about my goals for the month, and there‚Äôs so way to skip that and just go to the meditations.

Checking in is a fine thing to offer for people who want that, but why make it mandatory for all users? Anyway, I won‚Äôt be renewing my subscription anymore after it runs out next time. $99 a year is a lot when the app doesn‚Äôt even function the way I would like it to anymore.

title: Happier Meditation
content:
I had a dear friend who was suffering from pancreatic cancer, and I wanted to offer something that might useful, helpful, anything, really. I found Dan‚Äôs app through a list on a hospital website. The list provided sources for those who had not medicated but wanted in. I gave her a gift. It became a daily practice for her and for her husband who, I was told, said, ‚ÄúI wish I‚Äôd found this twenty years ago.‚Äù 
I have meditated for many years, but Dan‚Äôs app has been a perfect support for my practice. He seems to have found the sweet spot, something for everyone. The interviews alone are life changing. I am so grateful to Dan and the Ten Percent team. Honestly, I use the app every day, have gifted and recommended it countless times, shared interviews, found many enriching resource, etc. This is a beautiful bounty of powerful work. I highly recommend ‚ù§Ô∏è

title: Happier Meditation
content:
I unsubscribed after 5 years due to the new ‚Äúcheck in‚Äù landing page. I have paid the 100 bucks a year for 5 years. The content IS high quality.  Now, when you open the app, the landing page is an interactive ‚Äúcheck in.‚Äù  I have an extra click to get to a meditation. 
It would be great if they had a ‚Äúlifetime membership‚Äù price. After having paid $500 for the services of this app‚Äîit was worth it. I kinda wish it was paid for and I could just ride out this annoyance until they fix it.  But‚ÄîIt is too expensive to be broken/annoying.  
Every year, I decided‚Äî‚ÄúI get a lot out of this app, I will buy it again.‚Äù  But the landing page is a deal breaker.  If I were able to keep the whole app‚Äîfor free‚Äîfor what I have already paid, I would. But I cannot emphasize enough how much I hate the ‚Äúcheck in‚Äù as the landing page.  I tried checking in‚Äîughhh. If they want to offer a check-in section of the app‚Äîgreat! Offer check in. Offer journaling prompts. Offer habit checkers. BUT not on the landing page. ***A meditation should be on the landing page of the meditation app. It should be the first thing I see.

title: To Do List MinimaList & Widget
content: As a neurodivergent, adjusting to the changes in our necessary technological utilities, I have felt abandoned, and constantly on a fools journey. First and foremost prerequisite to be costly. While everything becomes itemised, the digital landscape is loud, over complicated, and unfamiliar. This app has given me the visual silence, the mental shelter for one‚Äôs sovereignty with one‚Äôs UX interface. It provided me the comfort to facilitate the very arduous bureaucratic red tape that limits and restricts our lives. I find myself ignoring most of the apps I use as my body learns to recognise them as piercing alarms of disparity. I like the soft features that feels ‚Äúsafe‚Äù to create- as it prioritises the functions, making the experience not a task, a chore, or a system to be coded, eroded, followed, or enslaved to. It is absent of useless defiances such as limitations on control, littered with ads or corners that jab sharply at the experience to just‚Ä¶execute. This app is order in the chaos. Identity for the disenfranchised users that have been left behind vulnerable to knavish tricks and policing user politics.

title: To Do List MinimaList & Widget
content: It would be nice if the widget could be set to dark mode. *Update* I got a response saying that I could set the widget to dark mode if I went to ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù and then ‚ÄúWidget Settings.‚Äù Of course, that is where I had gone the first time I tried to do this so I was skeptical. It turns out I was wrong. You CAN set the widget to dark mode in Settings but it is a bit complicated. On the ‚ÄúHomeScreen‚Äù page, you have to click on whichever list you want to use (or are already using) for your widget - Small List, Today, Medium List, or Large List. When you click on the list you‚Äôve chosen, a new screen with Options pops up. From the first page of the Options menu, you need to hit ‚ÄúNext‚Äù to get to the page where you can change the setting to Dark Mode, although make sure that you have a Source List selected otherwise you won‚Äôt be able to move forward to the next screen. On the next screen, there are 3 different ways to set the widget to dark mode. You can toggle the ‚ÄúAuto Dark Mode‚Äù button, select‚ÄúDark Mode Setting‚Äù or select any color for the background and text. Maybe my review should have said, ‚ÄúIt would be nice if setting the widget to dark mode were simpler or if could be done from the iPhone Home screen.‚Äù If I had gone through the app to add the widget to my Home screen, I might have seen this option at the beginning but since I added the app directly from my Home screen, I didn‚Äôt encounter these options in the process of setting it up. When I went looking for them later, it didn‚Äôt occur to me that I should look through the section for setting up the widget because mine was already set up.

author: yankading

title: Habitica: Gamified Taskmanager
content:
Excellent app, I enjoy using it all the time. It color codes your habits and daily tasks to let you know which are no being done. The gamification is a unique feature but it lacks incentives to want you to complete your habits. If there were benefits of having certain pets and mounts it would have been cool. Also there is a lack of quests and rewards. 

The biggest issue for me is the speed of the app, so many times I will complete a task it will lag and not complete. Even after refreshing it and closing the app, it only after a while the app will finally accept the input. The same goes for quest completion and starting, it‚Äôs super slow, not sure why that is but it‚Äôs super annoying. 

Overall this app has great potential and I still use it all the time. However, it can be far better.
author: Nicknamehasbeentaken

title: Habitica: Gamified Taskmanager
content: As an rpg nerd, There‚Äôs nothing like this app to help motivate me and trick me into building better habits and accomplishing my tasks to help me achieve my goal. When it works, I love it. The problem is that the app (and website) are completely reliant on having an online connection to function. So when habitica servers are down, the app is rendered useless. If the company could figure out a way to make the app available regardless of your internet access, I‚Äôd give it 5 stars. But till then, this is the best rating o can give to due to constant server interruptions.

author: mcculluhhh

title: Habitica: Gamified Taskmanager
content: I have tried almost every todo list, planner, calendar app on the App Store and even Android. This one is my favorite. The gamification is very good, and keeps you coming back. Other apps I get bored with, and few work to keep motivation so they dissolve quickly. The best part of the app to me is Task Value color coding. Just because I do something I need to do daily/weekly once doesn‚Äôt make me successful. I like that as I improve (example write recap email daily) the color goes up. If I start skipping or slacking in this area of work/life it goes red. This has helped me improve areas of my work, keeping my from having hard conversations later. I would like to see an Apple Watch app added would be nice. Also a calendar, and some statistics built into the app vs the Data Tool would make this perfect. Please add a calendar, stats, and notes (journaling). Even if you made this part of your subscription plan to access. Would pay for those features. Thanks for a good app.
